translated: because that which is not obtained has the nature of a characteristic, it does not occur in sequence.

analyzed: ajāta putra pitṛ śabda vat mahāmate krama vṛtti saṃbandha yogāḥ na ghaṭante
translated: O Great Being, like the words unborn son and father, the connections and relationships in sequence do not hold.

analyzed: tārkikāṇām hetu ārambaṇa nirantara adhipati pratyaya ādibhiḥ janya janaka tvāt mahāmate krama vṛttyā na utpadyante  parikalpita svabhāva abhiniveśa lakṣaṇāt mahāmate yugapad na utpadyante
translated: O Great Being, because of the cause, object, immediate condition, dominant condition, etc. of the logicians, they are not produced in sequence.🔽O Great Being, they are not produced simultaneously because of the characteristic of attachment to the imagined nature.

analyzed: sva citta dṛśya deha bhoga praviṣṭhāna tvāt sva sāmānya lakṣaṇa bāhya bhāva abhāvāt mahāmate krameṇa yugapad vā na utpadyante
translated: O Great Being, they are not produced either in sequence or simultaneously because of the absence of external things with general and specific characteristics, due to the entry into the body and enjoyment seen by one's own mind.

analyzed: anyatra sva citta dṛśya vikalpa vikalpita tvāt vijñānam pravartate
translated: Except for the discrimination of the seen and conceptualized by one's own mind, consciousness does not occur.

analyzed: tasmāt tarhi mahāmate hetu pratyaya kriyā yoga lakṣaṇa krama yugapad dṛṣṭi vigatena te bhavitavyam
translated: Therefore, O Great Being, you should be free from the views of cause, condition, action, yoga, sequence, and simultaneity.

analyzed: tatra idam ucyate
translated: Regarding this, it is said:

analyzed: na hi atra utpadyate kiṃcid pratyayaiḥ na nirudhyate
translated: For nothing is produced here by conditions, nor does it cease.

analyzed: utpadyante nirudhyante pratyayāḥ eva kalpitāḥ
translated: Only the imagined conditions are produced and cease.

analyzed: na bhaṅga utpāda saṃkleśaḥ pratyayānām nivāryate
translated: The defilement of production and cessation of conditions is not prevented.

original: yatra bālā vikalpanti pratyayaiḥ sa nivāryate // //
analyzed: yatra bālāḥ pratyayaiḥ sa nivāryate
translated: Where fools imagine with conditions, that is prevented.

analyzed: yat ca asataḥ pratyayeṣu dharmāṇām na asti saṃbhavaḥ
translated: And what does not exist in conditions, the non-existence of phenomena,

analyzed: vāsanaiḥ bhrāmitam cittam tri bhave khyāyate yatas
translated: From where the mind deluded by predispositions appears in the three existences,

analyzed: na a bhūtvā jāyate kiṃcid pratyayaiḥ na virudhyate
translated: Nothing is produced from non-existence by conditions, nor is it contradicted.

analyzed: vandhyā suta ākāśa puṣpam yadā paśyanti saṃskṛtam
translated: When one sees the dependent origination as the son of a barren woman or a sky-flower,

original: tadā grāhaśca grāhyaṃ ca bhrāntiṃ dṛṣṭvā nivartate // //🔽na cotpādyaṃ na cotpannaḥ pratyayo'pi na kiṃcana /
analyzed: tadā grāhaḥ ca grāhyam ca bhrāntim dṛṣṭvā nivartate  na ca utpādyam na ca utpannaḥ pratyayaḥ api na kiṃcana
translated: Then the grasper and the grasped, having seen delusion, turn back.🔽And the condition is not produced, nor is it produced at all.

analyzed: saṃvidyate kvacid kecid vayavahāraḥ tu kathyate
translated: It does not exist anywhere, yet the convention is said.

original: atha khalu mahāmatirbodhisattvo mahāsattvaḥ punarapi bhagavantametadavocatdeśayatu me bhagavān vāgvikalpalakṣaṇahṛdayaṃ nāma dharmaparyāyaṃ yena vāgvikalpalakṣaṇahṛdayena bhagavan suprativibhāgavinibaddhena ahaṃ ca anye ca bodhisattvā mahāsattvā abhilāpābhilāpyārthadvayagatiṃgatāḥ kṣipramanuttarāṃ samyaksaṃbodhimabhisaṃbudhya abhilāpābhilāpyārthadvayagatiṃ sarvasattvānāṃ viśodhayeyuḥ /
analyzed: atha khalu mahāmatiḥ bodhisattvaḥ mahāsattvaḥ punar api bhagavantam etat avocat deśayatu me bhagavān vāc vikalpa lakṣaṇa hṛdayam nāma dharmaparyāyam yena vāc vikalpa lakṣaṇa hṛdayena bhagavan suprativibhāga vinibaddhena aham ca anye ca bodhisattvāḥ mahāsattvāḥ abhilāpa abhilāpya artha dvaya gatiṃgatāḥ kṣipram anuttarām samyaksaṃbodhim abhisaṃbudhya abhilāpa abhilāpya artha dvaya gatim sarva sattvānām viśodhayeyuḥ
translated: Then indeed the bodhisattva mahāsattva Mahamati again said this to the Blessed One: May the Blessed One teach me the Dharma discourse called the Heart of the Characteristics of Verbal Discrimination, by which, Blessed One, well-connected with the Heart of the Characteristics of Verbal Discrimination, I and other bodhisattva mahāsattvas, having penetrated the two paths of verbal expression and the meaning to be expressed, will quickly fully awaken to unsurpassed perfect enlightenment and purify the two paths of verbal expression and the meaning to be expressed for all beings.

analyzed: bhagavān ahatena hi mahāmate śṛṇu
translated: The Blessed One said: Listen, Mahamati!

analyzed: sādhu ca suṣṭhu ca manasikuru
translated: Listen well and thoroughly, and keep it in mind.

analyzed: bhāṣiṣye iham te
translated: I will tell you.

original: sādhu bhagavan iti mahāmatirbodhisattvo mahāsattvo bhagavataḥ pratyaśrauṣīt /🔽bhagavānasyaitadavocat caturvidhaṃ mahāmate vāgvikalpalakṣaṇaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: sādhu bhagavan iti mahāmatiḥ bodhisattvaḥ mahāsattvaḥ bhagavataḥ pratyaśrauṣīt  bhagavān asya etat avocat caturvidham mahāmate vāc vikalpa lakṣaṇam bhavati
translated: Very well, Blessed One, the bodhisattva mahāsattva Mahamati replied to the Blessed One.

analyzed: yat uta lakṣaṇa vāc svapna vāc dauṣṭhulya vikalpa abhiniveśa vāc anādi vikalpa vāc
translated: The Blessed One said this to him: Mahamati, there are four kinds of characteristics of verbal discrimination, namely: the characteristic of verbal expression, the verbal expression of dreams, the verbal expression of attachment to the discrimination of unruliness, and the beginningless discrimination.

analyzed: tatra mahāmate lakṣaṇa vāc sva vikalpa rūpa nimitta abhiniveśāt pravartate
translated: There, Mahāmati, the speech of characteristics arises from the attachment to the signs of one's own conceptual forms.

analyzed: svapna vāc punar mahāmate pūrva anubhūta viṣaya anusmaraṇāt prativibuddha viṣaya abhāvāt ca pravartate
translated: Again, Mahāmati, the speech of dreams arises from the recollection of previously experienced objects and from the absence of objects upon awakening.

analyzed: dauṣṭhulya vikalpa abhiniveśa vāc punar mahāmate śatru pūrva kṛta karma anusmaraṇāt pravartate
translated: Again, Mahāmati, the speech of conceptual attachment to the unpleasant arises from the recollection of past actions done by enemies.

analyzed: anādi kāla vikalpa vāc punar mahāmate anādi kāla prapañca abhiniveśa dauṣṭhulya sva bīja vāsanātaḥ pravartate
translated: Again, Mahāmati, the speech of conceptualization from beginningless time arises from the habitual tendencies of one's own seeds of the unpleasant due to attachment to conceptual proliferation from beginningless time.

original: etaddhi mahāmate caturvidhaṃ vāgvikalpalakṣaṇamiti me yaduktam /
analyzed: etat hi mahāmate caturvidham vāc vikalpa lakṣaṇam iti me yat uktam
translated: This, Mahāmati, is the fourfold characteristic of verbal conceptualization that I have stated.

analyzed: idam tat pratyuktam
translated: This is the reply to that.

original: atha khalu mahāmatirbodhisattvo mahāsattvaḥ punarapi bhagavantametamevārthamadhyeṣate smadeśayatu me bhagavān punarapi vāgvikalpābhivyaktigocaram
analyzed: atha khalu mahāmatiḥ bodhisattvaḥ mahāsattvaḥ punar api bhagavantam etam eva artham adhyeṣate sma deśayatu me bhagavān punar api vāc vikalpa abhivyakti gocaram
translated: Then indeed the bodhisattva mahāsattva Mahāmati again requested the Blessed One to teach this very topic: May the Blessed One please teach me again the domain of the manifestation of verbal conceptualization,

original: kutra kasmāt kathaṃ kena bhagavan nṛṇāṃ vāgvijñaptivikalpaḥ pravartate /
analyzed: kutra kasmāt katham kena bhagavat nṛṇām vāc vijñapti vikalpaḥ pravartate
translated: where, why, how, and by what means, Blessed One, does the conceptualization of verbal expression arise in humans.

analyzed: bhagavān āha śira auraḥ nāsā kaṇṭha tālu oṣṭha jihvā danta samavāyāt mahāmate vāc pravartamānā pravartate
translated: The Blessed One said: Mahāmati, speech proceeds from the combination of head, throat, nose, palate, lips, tongue, and teeth.

original: mahāmatirāhakiṃ punarbhagavan vāg vikalpādanyā uta ananyā /
analyzed: mahāmatiḥ āha kim punar bhagavan vāc vikalpāt anyā uta ananyā
translated: Mahāmati said: But is speech different from conceptualization, or is it non-different?

original: bhagavānāhana hi mahāmate vāg vikalpādanyā nānanyā /
analyzed: bhagavān āha na hi mahāmate vāc vikalpāt anyā na ananyā
translated: The Blessed One said: Mahāmati, speech is neither different from conceptualization nor non-different.

analyzed: tat kasya hetoḥ
translated: Why is that?

analyzed: yat uta tad hetu utpatti lakṣaṇa tvāt mahāmate vāc vikalpaḥ pravartate
translated: Because, Mahāmati, speech proceeds from conceptualization due to the characteristic of arising from its cause.

analyzed: yadi punar mahāmate vāc vikalpāt anyā syāt
translated: But if, Mahāmati, speech were different from conceptualization,

analyzed: a vikalpa hetukī syāt
translated: it would arise without a cause for conceptualization.

analyzed: atha ananyā syāt
translated: If, on the other hand, it were non-different,

analyzed: artha abhivyakti tvāt vāc na kuryāt
translated: since it would manifest the meaning, speech would not do anything.

analyzed: sā ca kurute
translated: But it does do something.

analyzed: tasmāt na anyā na ananyā
translated: Therefore, it is neither different nor non-different.

analyzed: punar api mahāmatiḥ āha kim punar bhagavan vacanam eva paramārthaḥ
translated: Again, Mahāmati said: But, Blessed One, is speech itself the ultimate truth,

analyzed: uta yat vacanena abhilapyate sa paramārthaḥ
translated: or is that ultimate truth which is expressed by speech?

analyzed: bhagavān āhana mahāmate vacanam parama arthaḥ
translated: The Blessed One said: Mahāmati, speech is the ultimate truth,

analyzed: na ca yat vacanena abhilapyate sa paramārthaḥ
translated: but that which is expressed by speech is not the ultimate truth.

analyzed: tat kasya hetoḥ
translated: Why is that?

analyzed: yat uta paramārtha ārya sukha abhilāpa praveśi tvāt paramārthasya vacanam na paramārthaḥ
translated: Because the ultimate is entered through the expression of the supreme truth and bliss, the statement is not the ultimate truth.

analyzed: mahāmate ārya jñāna pratyātma gati gamyaḥ na vāc vikalpa buddhi gocaraḥ
translated: The ultimate, O Mahāmati, is to be realized by the noble knowledge of oneself, not by the domain of verbal discrimination and intellect.

analyzed: tena vikalpaḥ na udbhāvayati paramārtham
translated: Therefore, discrimination does not express the ultimate truth.

analyzed: vacanam punar mahāmate utpanna pradhvaṃsi capalam paraspara pratyaya hetu samutpannam
translated: Moreover, O Mahāmati, speech is produced and destroyed, fleeting, and arises from mutually dependent conditions.

analyzed: yat ca mahāmate paraspara pratyaya hetu samutpannam tat paramārtham nā udbhāvayati
translated: And what arises from mutually dependent conditions, O Mahāmati, does not express the ultimate truth.

analyzed: sva para lakṣaṇa abhāvāt mahāmate bāhya lakṣaṇam nā udbhāvayati
translated: Because of the absence of the characteristics of self and others, O Mahāmati, the external characteristics are not expressed.

analyzed: punar aparam mahāmate sva citta dṛśya mātra anusāri tvāt vividha vicitra lakṣaṇa bāhya bhāva abhāvāt vāc vikalpaḥ paramārtham na vikalpayati
translated: Moreover, O Mahāmati, because of following only what is seen in one's own mind, and because of the absence of various external things with various characteristics, verbal discrimination does not conceive of the ultimate truth.

analyzed: tasmāt tarhi mahāmate vāc vicitra vikalpa rahitena te bhavitavyam
translated: Therefore, O Mahāmati, you should be free from the various verbal discriminations.

analyzed: tatra idam ucyate
translated: Regarding this, it is said:

analyzed: sarva bhāvaḥ svabhāvaḥ hi sat vacanam tathā api asat
translated: All existences are without inherent nature. The true words are also non-existent.

analyzed: śūnyatā aśūnyatā artham vā bāla upaśyan vidhāvati
translated: Or the meaning of emptiness of emptiness, the fool runs without seeing.

analyzed: sarva bhāva svabhāvā ca vacanam api nṛṇām
translated: And the nature of all existences, even the words of men,

analyzed: kalpanā sā api nā asti nirvāṇam svapna tulyam
translated: That imagination also does not exist, nirvana is like a dream.

original: bhavaṃ parīkṣeta na saṃsāre nāpi nirvāyāt // //
analyzed: bhavam parīkṣeta na saṃsāre na api nirvāyāt
translated: One should examine existence, neither in samsara nor in nirvana.

analyzed: rājā śreṣṭhī yathā putrān vicitraiḥ mṛd mayaiḥ mṛgaiḥ
translated: Just as a king or a merchant, having enticed his sons with various clay animals,

original: pralobhya krīḍayitvā ca bhūtān dadyāttato mṛgān // //
analyzed: pralobhya krīḍayitvā ca bhūtān dadyāt tatas mṛgān
translated: Having amused them, would then give them the real animals.

analyzed: tathā aham lakṣaṇaiḥ citraiḥ dharmāṇām pratibimbakaiḥ
translated: In the same way, I, with various characteristics, with reflections of dharmas,

analyzed: pratyātma vedyām putrebhyaḥ bhūtakoṭim vadāmi aham
translated: I declare to my sons the peak of existence, which is to be known by each one's own self.

original: atha khalu mahāmatirbodhisattvo mahāsattvaḥ punarapi bhagavantametadavocatdeśayatu me bhagavān nāstyastitvaikatvānyatvobhayanobhayanaivāstinanāstinityānityavarjitaṃ sarvatīrthyāgatipracāramāryapratyātmajñānagatigamyaṃ parikalpitasvasāmānyalakṣaṇavinivṛttaṃ paramārthatattvāvatāraṃ bhūmyanusaṃdhikramottarottaraviśuddhilakṣaṇaṃ tathāgatabhūmyanupraveśalakṣaṇamanābhogapūrvapraṇidhānaviśvarūpamaṇisadṛśaviṣayānantalakṣaṇapracāraṃ svacittadṛśyagocaragativibhāgalakṣaṇaṃ sarvadharmāṇām /
analyzed: atha khalu mahāmatiḥ bodhisattvaḥ mahāsattvaḥ punar api bhagavantam etat avocat deśayatu me bhagavān sarva tīrthya āgati pracāram ārya pratyātma jñāna gati gamyam parikalpita sva sāmānya lakṣaṇa vinivṛttam paramārtha tattva avatāram bhūmi anusaṃdhi krama uttarottara viśuddhi lakṣaṇam tathāgata bhūmi anupraveśa lakṣaṇam anābhoga pūrva praṇidhāna viśvarūpa maṇi sadṛśa viṣaya ananta lakṣaṇa pracāram sva citta anupraveśa lakṣaṇam anābhoga pūrv
translated: Then indeed the bodhisattva mahāsattva Mahamati again said this to the Blessed One: May the Blessed One teach me the abandonment of existence and non-existence, oneness and otherness, both and neither, neither existence nor non-existence, permanence and impermanence, which is free from all tīrthika paths, to be understood by the noble ones through the knowledge of their own mind, which is turned away from the imagined specific and general characteristics, which is the entry into the highest truth, which has the characteristic of increasing purity stage by stage, which is the entry into the stage of the Tathāgatas, which is like a wish-fulfilling jewel in its endless activity of characteristics, which is the division of the domain of one's own mind's perceptions, of all dharmas.

original: yathā ca ahaṃ ca anye ca bodhisattvā mahāsattvā evamādiṣu parikalpitasvabhāvasvasāmānya lakṣaṇavinivṛttadṛṣṭayaḥ kṣipramanuttarāṃ samyaksaṃbodhimabhisaṃbudhya sarvasattvānāṃ sarvaguṇasaṃpattīḥ paripūrayema //
analyzed: yathā ca aham ca anye ca bodhisattvāḥ mahāsattvāḥ evamādiṣu parikalpita svabhāva sva sāmānya lakṣaṇa vinivṛtta dṛṣṭayaḥ kṣipram anuttarām samyaksaṃbodhim abhisaṃbudhya sarva sattvānām sarva guṇa saṃpattīḥ paripūrayema
translated: And so that I and other bodhisattva mahāsattvas, with views turned away from the imagined specific and general characteristics in this and other such [teachings], may quickly fully awaken to unsurpassed perfect enlightenment and fulfill all the perfections of all beings.

analyzed: bhagavān āha sādhu sādhu mahāmate
translated: The Blessed One said: Excellent, excellent, O Mahāmati!

analyzed: sādhu khalu punar tvam mahāmate
translated: Excellent, indeed, O Mahāmati,

analyzed: yat tvam etam artham adhyeṣitavyam manyase
translated: that you think to inquire about this matter.

original: bahujanahitāya tvaṃ mahāmate pratipanno bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāyai mahato janakāyasyārthāya hitāya sukhāya devānāṃ ca manuṣyāṇāṃ ca /
analyzed: bahu jana hitāya tvam mahāmate pratipannaḥ bahu jana sukhāya loka anukampāyai mahataḥ jana kāyasya arthāya hitāya sukhāya devānām ca manuṣyāṇām ca
translated: You are intent, O Mahāmati, on the welfare of many people, on the happiness of many people, out of compassion for the world, for the sake of the multitude, for the welfare, benefit, and happiness of gods and human beings.

analyzed: tena hi mahāmate śṛṇu
translated: Therefore, O Mahāmati, listen.

original: sādhu ca suṣṭhu ca manasi kuru /
analyzed: sādhu ca suṣṭhu ca manasi kuru
translated: Listen well and reflect properly.

analyzed: bhāviṣyā iham te
translated: I will tell you.

original: sādhu bhagavanniti mahāmatirbodhisattvo mahāsattvo bhagavataḥ pratyaśrauṣīt /
analyzed: sādhu bhagavan iti mahāmatiḥ bodhisattvaḥ mahāsattvaḥ bhagavataḥ pratyaśrauṣīt
translated: Excellent, Blessed One! said the bodhisattva mahāsattva Mahāmati, and he listened to the Blessed One.

analyzed: bhagavān tasya etat avocat sva citta dṛśya mātra anavabodhāt mahāmate bāla pṛthagjanāḥ bāhya vicitra bhāva abhiniveśena ca vikalpayanti
translated: The Blessed One said this to him: O Mahāmati, due to not understanding that what appears is one's own mind only, foolish ordinary people, by clinging to external various things, cling to existence and non-existence, oneness and otherness, both and neither, permanence and impermanence, and to the causes of habitual tendencies, and they conceptualize.

original: tadyathā mahāmate mṛgatṛṣṇodakaṃ mṛgā udakabhāvena vikalpya grīṣmābhitaptāḥ pātukāmatayā pradhāvanti /
analyzed: tat yathā mahāmate mṛgatṛṣṇā udakam mṛgāḥ udaka bhāvena vikalpya grīṣma abhitaptāḥ pātu kāma tayā pradhāvanti
translated: Just as, Mahāmati, deer, tormented by the heat of summer, seeing mirage as water, imagine it to be water, and run towards it with the desire to drink,

analyzed: sva citta dṛṣṭi bhrānti anavabodhāt na prajānanti na atra udakam iti
translated: because they do not understand the error of their own mind's vision, they do not know that there is no water here.

original: evameva mahāmate bālapṛthagjanā anādikālavividhaprapañcavikalpavāsitamatayo rāgadveṣamohāgnitāpitamanaso vicitrarūpaviṣayābhilāṣiṇaḥ utpādabhaṅgasthitidṛṣṭyāśayā ādhyātmikabāhyabhāvābhāvākuśalāḥ /
analyzed: evam eva mahāmate bāla pṛthagjanāḥ anādi kāla vividha prapañca vikalpa vāsita matayaḥ rāga dveṣa moha agni tāpita manasaḥ vicitra rūpa viṣaya abhilāṣiṇaḥ utpāda bhaṅga sthiti dṛṣṭi āśayāḥ ādhyātmika bāhya bhāva abhāva akuśalāḥ
translated: In the same way, Mahāmati, foolish ordinary people, whose minds are perfumed by various conceptual proliferations since beginningless time, whose minds are heated by the fires of passion, hatred, and delusion, who desire various forms and objects, whose intentions are based on the view of origination, cessation, and duration, who are unskilled in the existence and non-existence of internal and external things,

analyzed: te ekatva anyatva nāstyastitva grāhe prapatanti
translated: they fall into the grasping of identity, difference, non-existence, and existence.

analyzed: tat yathā mahāmate gandharvanagare viduṣām anagare nagara saṃjñā bhavati
translated: Just as, Mahāmati, in a gandharva city, the ignorant have the notion of a city where there is no city,

analyzed: sā ca nagara ākṛtiḥ anādi kāla nagara bīja vāsanā abhiniveśāt khyāti
translated: and that city-like appearance is known because of the attachment to the seed of a city perfumed since beginningless time,

analyzed: tat ca nagaram na anagaram na nagaram
translated: and that city is neither a city nor not a city.

analyzed: evam eva mahāmate anādi kāla tīrthya praprañca vāda vāsanā abhiniviṣṭāḥ ekatva anyatva astitva nāstitva vādān abhiniviśante sva citta dṛśya mātra anavadhārita matayaḥ
translated: In the same way, Mahāmati, those who are attached to the discourses of non-Buddhist philosophers from beginningless time, with minds not discerning that [the world] is merely appearances of their own minds, become attached to the discourses of identity, difference, existence, and non-existence.

original: tadyathā mahāmate kaścideva puruṣaḥ śayitaḥ svapnāntare strīpuruṣahastyaśvarathapadātigrāmanagaranigamagomahiṣavanodyānavividhagirinadītaḍāgopaśobhitaṃ janapadamantaḥpuraṃ praviśya prativibudhyeta /
analyzed: tat yathā mahāmate kaścid eva puruṣaḥ śayitaḥ svapna antare strī puruṣa hasti aśva ratha padāti grāma nagara nigama go mahiṣa vana udyāna vividha giri nadī taḍāga upaśobhitam janapadam antaḥpuram praviśya prativibudhyeta
translated: Just as, Mahāmati, a certain man, while sleeping, enters a palace in a dream, adorned with women, men, elephants, horses, chariots, infantry, villages, towns, cities, cows, buffaloes, forests, gardens, various mountains, rivers, ponds, and enters a country, and awakens.

analyzed: sa prativibuddhaḥ san tat eva janapadam antaḥpuram samanusmaret
translated: Having awakened, he would remember that very country and palace.

original: tatkiṃ manyase mahāmateapi nu sa puruṣaḥ paṇḍitajātīyo bhavet /
analyzed: tat kim manyase mahāmate api nu sa puruṣaḥ paṇḍita jātīyaḥ bhavet
translated: What do you think, Mahāmati, would that man be of the type of a wise one,

analyzed: yaḥ tat abhūtam svapna vaicitryam anusmaret
translated: who would remember that unreal variety of dreams?

analyzed: āhanaḥ hi idam bhagavan
translated: He said: No indeed, Blessed One.

original: bhagavānāhaevameva mahāmate bālapṛthagjanāḥ kudṛṣṭidaṣṭāstīrthyamatayaḥ svapnatulyātsvacittadṛśyabhāvānna prativijānante /
analyzed: bhagavān āha evam eva mahāmate bāla pṛthagjanāḥ kudṛṣṭi daṣṭāḥ tīrthya matayaḥ svapna tulyāt sva citta dṛśya bhāvāt na prativijānante
translated: The Blessed One said: In the same way, Mahāmati, foolish ordinary people, bitten by wrong views, with the minds of non-Buddhist philosophers, do not understand that the appearances of their own minds are like a dream.

analyzed: ekatva anyatva nāstyastitva dṛṣṭim samāśrayante
translated: They rely on the views of existence and non-existence of oneness and otherness.

original: tadyathā mahāmate citrakarakṛtapradeśā animnonnatāḥ santo nimnonnatā bālaiḥ kalpyante /
analyzed: tat yathā mahāmate citrakara kṛta pradeśāḥ a nimna unnatāḥ santaḥ nimna unnatāḥ bālaiḥ kalpyante
translated: Just as, O Mahāmati, the regions created by a painter are not low and high, yet the foolish imagine them to be low and high.

analyzed: evam eva mahāmate bhaviṣyanti anāgata idhvani tīrthya dṛṣṭi vāsanā āśaya prativikalpa puṣṭāḥ
translated: In the same way, O Mahāmati, in the future there will be those who are nourished by the conceptual thoughts of the inclinations and dispositions of the views of the tīrthikas.

original: te ekatvānyatvobhayānubhayavādābhiniviṣṭāḥ svayaṃ naṣṭā anyānapi sadasatpakṣaviviktānutpādavādino nāstikā iti vakṣyanti /🔽ete hetuphalāpavādino durdarśanonmūlitahetukuśalaśuklapakṣāḥ /
analyzed: te ekatva anyatva ubhaya anubhaya vāda abhiniviṣṭāḥ svayam naṣṭāḥ anyān api sat asat pakṣa vivikta anutpāda vādinaḥ nāstikāḥ iti vakṣyanti  ete hetu phala apavādinaḥ durdarśana unmūlita hetu kuśala śuklapakṣāḥ
translated: They will be attached to the doctrines of oneness, otherness, both, and neither. They will themselves be lost and will say that others who teach the doctrine of non-arising, free from the extremes of existence and non-existence, are atheists.

analyzed: ete śreyaḥ ṛthibhiḥ dūratas iti vakṣyante
translated: They will say that these [teachers] who deny cause and effect are to be shunned from afar by those who seek the highest good, as they are uprooted by the wrong view of nihilism, which destroys the wholesome and virtuous side that is based on cause.

analyzed: te ca sva para ubhaya dṛṣṭi patita āśayāḥ nāstyastitva vikalpa samāropa apavāda kudṛṣṭi patita āśayāḥ naraka parāyaṇāḥ bhaviṣyanti
translated: And those whose inclinations fall into the views of self, other, and both, and who fall into the wrong views of superimposition and denial regarding the conceptual thoughts of existence and non-existence, will be destined for hell.

original: tadyathā mahāmate taimirikāḥ keśoṇḍukaṃ dṛṣṭvā parasparamācakṣateiadaṃ citramidaṃ citramiti paśyantu bho mārṣāḥ /
analyzed: tat yathā mahāmate taimirikāḥ keśoṇḍukam dṛṣṭvā parasparam ācakṣate idam citram idam citram iti paśyantu bho mārṣāḥ
translated: Just as, O Mahāmati, those with eye disease, seeing a hair-net, say to each other, 'Look, friends, at this marvel, at this marvel!'

original: tacca keśoṇḍukamubhayānutpannatayā na bhāvo nābhāvo darśanādarśanataḥ /
analyzed: tat ca keśoṇḍukam ubhaya anutpanna tayā na bhāvaḥ na abhāvaḥ darśana adarśanataḥ
translated: And that hair-tuft, being unborn in both ways, is neither existent nor non-existent, due to being seen and not seen.

original: evameva mahāmate tīrthyakudṛṣṭivikalpāśayābhiniviṣṭāḥ sadasatpakṣaikatvānyatvobhayānubhayatvavādābhiniviṣṭāḥ saddharmāpavādakā ātmānaṃ parāṃśca vinipātayiṣyanti /
analyzed: evam eva mahāmate tīrthya kudṛṣṭi vikalpa āśaya abhiniviṣṭāḥ sat asat pakṣa ekatva anyatva ubhaya anubhaya tva vāda abhiniviṣṭāḥ saddharma apavādakāḥ ātmānam parān ca vinipātayiṣyanti
translated: In the same way, Mahāmati, those who are attached to the views and intentions of the tīrthikas and non-Buddhists, who are attached to the doctrines of existence and non-existence, oneness and otherness, both and neither, and who slander the true Dharma, will cause themselves and others to fall.

original: tadyathā mahāmate acakramalātacakraṃ bālaiścakrabhāvena parikalpyate na paṇḍitaiḥ /
analyzed: tat yathā mahāmate acakram alāta cakram bālaiḥ cakra bhāvena parikalpyate na paṇḍitaiḥ
translated: Just as, Mahāmati, an unmoving fire-brand circle is imagined by fools to be a circle, but not by the wise.

original: evameva mahāmate kudṛṣṭitīrthyāśayapatitā ekatvānyatvobhayānubhayatvaṃ parikalpayiṣyanti sarvabhāvotpattau /
analyzed: evam eva mahāmate kudṛṣṭi tīrthya āśaya patitāḥ ekatva anyatva ubhaya anubhaya tvam parikalpayiṣyanti sarva bhāva utpattau
translated: In the same way, Mahāmati, those who have fallen into the views and intentions of the tīrthikas and non-Buddhists will imagine oneness, otherness, both and neither in the arising of all things.

original: tadyathā mahāmate deve pravarṣati jalabudbudakāḥ sphaṭikamaṇisadṛśāḥ khyāyante /
analyzed: tat yathā mahāmate deve pravarṣati jala budbudakāḥ sphaṭika maṇi sadṛśāḥ khyāyante
translated: Just as, Mahāmati, when the gods rain, water bubbles appear resembling crystal gems.

analyzed: tatra ca bālāḥ sphaṭika maṇi bhāvam abhiniveśya pradhāvanti
translated: And there, the fools, being attached to the idea of crystal gems, run towards them.

original: te ca mahāmate udakabudbudakā na maṇayo nāmaṇayo grahaṇāgrahaṇataḥ /
analyzed: te ca mahāmate udaka budbudakāḥ na maṇayaḥ na a maṇayaḥ grahaṇa a grahaṇataḥ
translated: But, Mahāmati, those water bubbles are neither gems nor not gems, due to being grasped and not grasped.

original: evameva mahāmate tīrthyadṛṣṭivikalpāśayavāsanāvāsitā asataścotpādaṃ varṇayiṣyanti pratyayaiḥ /
analyzed: evam eva mahāmate tīrthya dṛṣṭi vikalpa āśaya vāsanā vāsitāḥ asataḥ ca utpādam varṇayiṣyanti pratyayaiḥ
translated: In the same way, Mahāmati, those whose minds are polluted by the views and concepts of the tīrthikas will describe the arising of the non-existent through conditions.

analyzed: sataḥ ca vināśam
translated: And the destruction of the existent.

original: punaraparaṃ mahāmate pramāṇatrayāvayavapratyavasthānaṃ kṛtvā āryajñānapratyātmādhigamyaṃ svabhāvadvayavinirmuktaṃ vastu svabhāvato vidyata iti vikalpayiṣyanti /
analyzed: punar aparam mahāmate pramāṇa traya avayava pratyavasthānam kṛtvā ārya jñāna pratyātma adhigamyam svabhāva dvaya vinirmuktam vastu svabhāvataḥ vidyate iti vikalpayiṣyanti
translated: Moreover, Mahāmati, having established the three means of valid knowledge, they will conceptualize that an entity exists by its own nature, which is free from the two natures and is to be realized by the noble knowledge of oneself.

original: na ca mahāmate cittamano manovijñānacittaparāvṛttyāśrayāṇāṃ svacittadṛśyagrāhyagrāhakavikalpaprahīṇānāṃ tathāgatabhūmipratyātmāryajñānagatānāṃ yogināṃ bhāvābhāvasaṃjñā pravartate /
analyzed: na ca mahāmate citta manaḥ manaḥ vijñāna citta parāvṛtti āśrayāṇām sva citta dṛśya grāhya grāhaka vikalpa prahīṇānām tathāgata bhūmi pratyātma ārya jñāna gatānām yoginām bhāva abhāva saṃjñā pravartate
translated: But, Mahāmati, for those who have turned away from the mind, thought, and mental consciousness, who are free from the conceptualization of their own mind's perception of the graspable and grasper, who have attained the noble knowledge of the Tathāgata stage, the notion of existence and non-existence does not occur.

analyzed: yadi punar mahāmate yoginām evaṃgati viṣayāṇām bhāva abhāva grāhaḥ pravartate
translated: If, Mahāmati, the notion of existence and non-existence were to occur for yogins who have such a range of experience,

original: sa evaiṣāmātmagrāhaḥ poṣagrāhaḥ puruṣagrāhaḥ pudgalagrāhaḥ syāt /
analyzed: saḥ eva eṣām ātma grāhaḥ poṣa grāhaḥ puruṣa grāhaḥ pudgala grāhaḥ syāt
translated: that would be their grasping at self, grasping at nourishment, grasping at person, and grasping at individual.

analyzed: yā punar evam mahāmate bhāva svabhāva sva sāmānya lakṣaṇa deśanā
translated: Now, Mahāmati, this teaching on the nature and characteristics of entities, both their own and general,

analyzed: eṣā mahāmate nairmāṇika buddha deśanāḥ na dharmatā buddha deśanā
translated: This, O Mahāmati, is the teaching of the Nirmanakaya Buddha, not the teaching of the Dharmakaya Buddha.

analyzed: deśanā punar mahāmate bāla śaya gata dṛṣṭi pravṛttā
translated: Moreover, O Mahāmati, the teaching is based on the views of the childish.

analyzed: na ca pratyavasthāna gati svabhāva dharma ārya jñāna pratyātma adhigama samādhi sukha vihāram udbhāvayati
translated: It does not proclaim the bliss of abiding in the concentration that is the noble knowledge and self-realization of the nature of the mind that is free from conceptual proliferation.

analyzed: tat yathā mahāmate jala antargatā vṛkṣa chāyā khyāyate
translated: Just as, O Mahāmati, the shadow of a tree appears in the water,

original: sā ca na cchāyā nācchāyā vṛkṣasaṃsthānāsaṃsthānataḥ /
analyzed: sā ca na chāyā na acchāyā vṛkṣa saṃsthāna asaṃsthānataḥ
translated: and that is neither a shadow nor not a shadow, because of the form of the tree and its lack of form,

analyzed: evam eva mahāmate tīrthya dṛṣṭi vāsanā vāsita vikalpāḥ ekatva anyatva ubhaya tva anubhaya tva nāstyastitvam vikalpayiṣyanti sva citta dṛśya mātra anavadhārita matayaḥ
translated: in the same way, O Mahāmati, those whose minds are tainted by the imprints of the views of the tīrthikas will conceive of oneness, otherness, both, neither, existence, and non-existence, due to their discrimination, not realizing that it is their own mind that is seen.

original: tadyathā mahāmate darpaṇāntargatāni sarvarūpapratibimbakāni khyāyante yathāpratyayataḥ svavikalpanācca /
analyzed: tat yathā mahāmate darpaṇa antargatāni sarva rūpa pratibimbakāni khyāyante yathā pratyayataḥ sva vikalpanāt ca
translated: Just as, O Mahāmati, all the reflections of forms appear in a mirror according to the conditions and one's own imagination,

analyzed: na tāni bimbāni na abimbāni bimba abimba darśanataḥ
translated: those are neither forms nor not forms, because of the appearance of forms and non-forms.

original: atha ca te mahāmate svacittadṛśyavikalpāḥ khyāyante bālānāṃ bimbākṛtayaḥ /
analyzed: atha ca te mahāmate sva citta dṛśya vikalpāḥ khyāyante bālānām bimba ākṛtayaḥ
translated: And yet, O Mahāmati, those conceptual thoughts of one's own mind that are seen appear to the childish in the form of forms.

analyzed: evam eva mahāmate sva citta pratibimbāni khyāyante ekatva anyatva ubhaya anubhaya dṛṣṭi ākāreṇa
translated: In the same way, O Mahāmati, the reflections of one's own mind appear in the form of the views of oneness, otherness, both, and neither.

analyzed: tat yathā mahāmate pratiśrutkā puruṣa nadī pavana saṃyogāt pravartamānā anuśrūyate
translated: Just as, O Mahāmati, an echo is heard when a man, a river, and a wind come together,

original: sā ca na bhāvā nābhāvā ghoṣāghoṣaśravaṇataḥ /
analyzed: sā ca na bhāvā na abhāvā ghoṣa aghoṣa śravaṇataḥ
translated: and that is neither existent nor non-existent, because of hearing sound and no sound,

analyzed: evam eva mahāmate khyāyante
translated: in the same way, O Mahāmati, the views of existence and non-existence, oneness and otherness, both and neither, arise from the conceptual thoughts of one's own mind.

analyzed: tat yathā mahāmate nistṛṇa gulma latā vanāyām medinyām āditya saṃyogāt mṛgatṛṣṇikāḥ taraṃga vat syandante
translated: Just as, O Mahāmati, in a land devoid of grass, shrubs, and creepers, mirage-like waves flow from the conjunction with the sun,

original: te ca na bhāvā nābhāvā lobhyālobhyataḥ /
analyzed: te ca na bhāvāḥ na abhāvāḥ lobhya alobhyataḥ
translated: and they are neither existent nor non-existent, because of being desirable and undesirable,

analyzed: evam eva mahāmate bālānām anādi kāla prapañca dauṣṭhulya vāsanā vāsitam vikalpa vijñānam utpāda sthiti bhaṅga ekatva anyatva ubhaya anubhaya nāstyastyārya pratyātma jñāna vastu mukhena mṛgatṛṣṇikā vat taraṃgāyate
translated: in the same way, O Mahāmati, the consciousness of conceptual thoughts, which is infused with the latent tendencies of the beginningless proliferation of mental afflictions in the minds of fools, appears like waves in a mirage, through the objects of the knowledge of noble ones that is free from arising, abiding, and ceasing, oneness and otherness, both and neither, existence and non-existence.

original: tadyathā mahāmate vetālayantrapuruṣau niḥsattvau piśācayuktigātspandanakriyāṃ kurvāte /
analyzed: tat yathā mahāmate vetāla yantra puruṣau niḥsattvau piśāca yuktigāt spandana kriyām kurvāte
translated: Just as, Great Being, a vetāla and a mechanical man, being without substance, perform the action of moving through the power of a ghost's magic,

original: tatra ca asadvikalpe bālā abhiniviśante gamanāgamanataḥ /
analyzed: tatra ca asat vikalpe bālāḥ abhiniviśante gamana agamanataḥ
translated: and in that false imagination, fools become attached to it through coming and going.

analyzed: evam eva mahāmate bāla pṛthagjanāḥ kudṛṣṭi tīrthya āśaya patitāḥ ekatva anyatva vādān abhiniviśante
translated: In the same way, Great Being, foolish ordinary people, fallen into the intentions of those with wrong views and tīrthikas, become attached to the doctrines of oneness and otherness.

analyzed: sa ca asat bhūta samāropaḥ
translated: And that is the superimposition of what is unreal.

analyzed: tasmāt tarhi mahāmate utpāda sthiti bhaṅga ekatva anyatva ubhaya anubhaya nāstyastyārya pratyātma vastu adhigama vikalpa rahitena bhavitavyam
translated: Therefore, Great Being, one should be free from the conceptualization of origination, duration, and destruction, oneness, otherness, both, neither, non-existence, existence, and the realization of the object of the noble ones in one's own mind.

analyzed: tatra idam ucyate
translated: Regarding this, it is said:

analyzed: jala vṛkṣa chāyā sadṛśāḥ skandhāḥ vijñāna pañcamāḥ
translated: The aggregates, along with consciousness as the fifth, are like the shadow of a tree in water.

analyzed: māyā svapna upamādṛśāśyā
translated: They should be seen as similar to an illusion or a dream.

analyzed: vijñaptyā mā vikalpayate
translated: Do not conceptualize them through representation.

analyzed: keśoṇḍuka prakhyam idam marīci udaka vibhramat
translated: This is like a hair-net, a mirage, or a delusion of water.

analyzed: tri bhavam svapna māyā ākhyam vimucyate
translated: One is liberated by realizing the three realms to be like a dream or an illusion.

analyzed: mṛgatṛṣṇā yathā grīṣme spandate citta mohanī
translated: Just as a mirage shimmers in the summer, deluding the mind,

original: mṛgā gṛhṇanti pānīyaṃ na cāsyāṃ vastu vidyate // //
analyzed: mṛgāḥ gṛhṇanti pānīyam na ca asyām vastu vidyate  /
translated: deer take it to be water, but in reality it does not exist.

analyzed: tathā vijñāna bījam hi spandate dṛṣṭi gocare
translated: Likewise, the seed of consciousness vibrates in the range of vision.

original: bālā gṛhṇanti jāyantaṃ timiraṃ taimirā yathā // //
analyzed: bālāḥ gṛhṇanti jāyantam timiram taimirāḥ yathā
translated: The ignorant grasp it as born, like the cataract of those with cataracts.

analyzed: anādi gati saṃsāre bhāva grāha upagūhitam
translated: In the beginningless cycle of existence, obscured by the grasping of entities,

original: bālaḥ kīle yathā kīlaṃ pralobhya vinivartayet // //
analyzed: bālaḥ kīle yathā kīlam pralobhya vinivartayet
translated: The child, like a peg drawing out a peg, should be turned away from attachment.

analyzed: māyā vetāla yantra ābham svapna vidyut dhanam sadā
translated: Like an illusion, a ghost, a machine, always like a dream, lightning, and wealth,

analyzed: tri saṃtati vyavacchinnam jagat paśya n vimucyate
translated: Seeing the world cut off from the three continuums, one is liberated.

analyzed: na hi atra kācid vijñaptiḥ marīcīnām yathā nabhe
translated: For here there is no manifestation at all, like the mirage in the sky.

analyzed: evam dharmān vijānantaḥ na kiṃcid pratijānate
translated: Thus, knowing phenomena, one does not know anything.

analyzed: vijñaptiḥ nāma mātrā iyam lakṣaṇena na vidyate
translated: This manifestation is mere name, it does not exist by characteristic.

analyzed: skandhāḥ keśoṇḍuka ākārāḥ yatra ca asau vikalpyate  /
translated: The aggregates are like a hair-ball, where this is imagined.

original: cittaṃ keśoṇḍukaṃ māyāṃ svapna gandharvameva ca /
analyzed: cittam keśoṇḍukam māyām svapna gandharvam eva ca
translated: Mind, hair-ball, illusion, dream, and gandharva,

original: alātaṃ mṛgatṛṣṇā ca asantaḥ khyāti vai nṛṇām // //
analyzed: alātam mṛgatṛṣṇā ca asantaḥ khyāti vai nṛṇām
translated: A fire-brand, and a mirage, the unreal appears to men.

analyzed: nitya anityam tathā ekatvam ubhayam na ubhayam tathā
translated: Permanence and impermanence, likewise oneness, both, and neither,

analyzed: anādi doṣa saṃbandhāt bālāḥ kalpanti mohitāḥ
translated: The ignorant imagine, deluded, due to beginningless connection with faults.

original: darpaṇe udake netre bhāṇḍeṣu ca maṇīṣu ca /
analyzed: darpaṇe udake netre bhāṇḍeṣu ca maṇīṣu ca
translated: In a mirror, in water, in the eyes, and in vessels and gems,

original: bimbaṃ hi dṛśyate teṣu bimbaṃ nāsti ca kutracid // //
analyzed: bimbam hi dṛśyate teṣu bimbam na asti ca kutracid
translated: The reflection is seen, but the reflection does not exist anywhere.

original: bhāvābhāsaṃ tathā cittaṃ mṛgatṛṣṇā yathā nabhe /
analyzed: bhāva ābhāsam tathā cittam mṛgatṛṣṇā yathā nabhe
translated: Likewise, the mind appears as an existent, like a mirage in the sky,

analyzed: dṛśyate citra rūpeṇa svapne vandhyā aurasaḥ yathā
translated: Seen with various forms, like a barren woman's son in a dream.

analyzed: punar aparam mahāmate catuṣṭaya vinirmuktā tathāgatānām dharma deśanā
translated: Moreover, Mahāmati, the Tathāgatas' teaching of the Dharma is free from the four [extremes],

analyzed: yat uta ekatva anyatva ubhaya anubhaya pakṣa vivarjitā
translated: That is to say, it is free from the positions of oneness, otherness, both, and neither, and is free from the superimposition and denial of existence and non-existence.

analyzed: asatya pratītyasamutpāda nirodha mārga vimokṣa pravṛtti pūrvakā mahāmate tathāgatānām dharma deśanā
translated: Mahāmati, the Tathāgatas' teaching of the Dharma proceeds from the cessation of the non-existent dependent origination, the path, and liberation.

analyzed: na prakṛti īśvara hetu yadṛcchā aṇu kāla svabhāva upanibaddhā mahāmate tathāgatānām dharma deśanā
translated: Mahāmati, the Tathāgatas' teaching of the Dharma is not bound to the nature, Īśvara, cause, chance, atom, or time.

original: punaraparaṃ mahāmate kleśajñeyāvaraṇadvayaviśuddhyarthaṃ sārthavāhavadānupūrvyā aṣṭottare nirābhāsapadaśate pratiṣṭhāpayanti yānabhūmyaṅgasuvibhāgalakṣaṇe ca //
analyzed: punar aparam mahāmate kleśa jñeya āvaraṇa dvaya viśuddhi artham sārthavāha vat ānupūrvyā aṣṭa uttare nirābhāsa pada śate pratiṣṭhāpayanti yāna bhūmi aṅga suvibhāga lakṣaṇe ca
translated: Moreover, Mahāmati, in order to purify the two obscurations of afflictions and the knowable, [the Tathāgatas] establish [beings] in the one hundred and eight stages of non-appearance, in the sequence of the caravan leader, which is characterized by the well-differentiated aspects of the vehicles and stages.

analyzed: punar aparam mahāmate caturvidham dhyānam
translated: Moreover, Mahāmati, there are four kinds of meditation.

analyzed: katamat caturvidham
translated: And what are the four kinds?

analyzed: yat uta bāla upacārikam dhyānam  artha pravicayam dhyānam
translated: Namely, the meditation of childish practice,🔽the meditation of investigating the meaning,

analyzed: tathatā ālambanam dhyānam
translated: the meditation of taking the suchness as the object,

analyzed: tāthāgatam caturtham dhyānam
translated: and the fourth meditation of the Tathāgatas.

analyzed: tatra mahāmate bāla upacārikam dhyānam katamat
translated: Among them, Mahāmati, what is the meditation of childish practice?

analyzed: yat uta śrāvaka pratyekabuddha yoga yoginām pudgala nairātmya bhāva sva sāmānya bimba saṃkalā nitya duḥkha aśubha lakṣaṇa abhiniveśa pūrvakam
translated: Namely, it is the meditation of the śrāvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and yogis, preceded by the attachment to the characteristics of the non-self of persons, the existence of the self, the general and specific characteristics, the impermanence, suffering, and impurity of one's own [mind],

original: evamidaṃ lakṣaṇaṃ nānyatheti paśyataḥ pūrvottarottarata ā saṃjñānirodhādbālopacārikaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: evam idam lakṣaṇam na anyathā iti paśyataḥ pūrva uttara uttaratas ā saṃjñā nirodhāt bāla upacārikam bhavati
translated: thinking, This characteristic is like this, not otherwise, from the beginning up to the cessation of conceptualization, it becomes [the meditation] of childish practice.

analyzed: tatra artha pravicaya dhyānam punar mahāmate katamat
translated: Among them, Mahāmati, what is the meditation of investigating the meaning?

analyzed: yat uta pudgala nairātmya sva sāmānya lakṣaṇa bāhya tīrthakara sva para ubhaya abhāvam kṛtvā dharma nairātmya bhūmi lakṣaṇa artham pravicaya anupūrvakam artha pravicaya dhyānam bhavati
translated: Namely, having made the non-self of persons, the general and specific characteristics, the external tīrthikas, and the non-existence of both self and others, one investigates the characteristics and meaning of the stages of the non-self of phenomena in sequence, it becomes the meditation of investigating the meaning.

analyzed: tatra tathatā ālambanam dhyānam mahāmate katamat
translated: Among them, O Mahāmati, what is the meditation with suchness as its object?

analyzed: yat uta parikalpita nairātmya dvaya vikalpa yathā bhūta avasthānāt apravṛtteḥ vikalpasya tathatā ālambanam iti vadāmi
translated: Namely, when the discrimination of the two kinds of imagined selflessness does not arise due to the correct establishment of suchness, I say it is with suchness as its object.

analyzed: tāthāgatam punar mahāmate dhyānam katamat
translated: Again, O Mahāmati, what is the meditation of the Tathāgata?

analyzed: yat uta tāthāgata bhūmi ākāra praveśam pratyātma ārya jñāna lakṣaṇa traya sukha vihāra acintya sattva kṛtya karaṇatayā tāthāgatam dhyānam iti vadāmi
translated: Namely, I say the meditation of the Tathāgata is due to entering the aspects of the stage of the Tathāgata, abiding in the bliss of the three characteristics of the knowledge of the noble ones in oneself, and accomplishing the inconceivable activities for beings.

analyzed: tatra idam ucyate
translated: Regarding that, this is said:

analyzed: artha pravicayam dhyānam dhyānam bāla upacārikam
translated: The meditation of discerning the meaning, the meditation that is a convention for fools,

analyzed: tathatā ālambanam dhyānam dhyānam tāthāgatam śubham
translated: The meditation with suchness as its object, the meditation of the auspicious Tathāgata.

analyzed: soma bhāskara saṃsthānam padma pātāla sādṛśam
translated: Resembling the forms of the moon and sun, like a lotus or the underworld,

analyzed: gagana agni citra sadṛśam yogī yuñjan prapaśyati
translated: The yogin practicing sees it resembling space or fire.

original: nimittāni ca citrāṇi tīrthamārgaṃ nayanti te /
analyzed: nimittāni ca citrāṇi tīrtha mārgam nayanti te
translated: And the various signs lead them to the path of the tīrthikas,

analyzed: śrāvaka tve pratyeka jina gocare
translated: They fall into the state of a śrāvaka or the domain of a pratyekabuddha.

analyzed: vidhūya sarvāṇi etāni nirābhāsam yadā bhavet
translated: Having shaken off all these, when there is freedom from appearances,

analyzed: tadā buddha ākara ādityāḥ sarva kṣetrāḥ samāgatāḥ
translated: Then the Buddhas, the Suns, from the Buddha-fields, all assembled,

original: śiro hi tasya mārjanti nimittaṃ tathatānugam // //
analyzed: śiraḥ hi tasya mārjanti nimittam tathatā anugam
translated: Wipe the dust from his head, following the sign of Suchness.

original: atha khalu mahāmatirbodhisattvo mahāsattvaḥ punarapi bhagavantametadavocatnirvāṇaṃ nirvāṇamiti bhagavannucyate /
analyzed: atha khalu mahāmatiḥ bodhisattvaḥ mahāsattvaḥ punar api bhagavantam etat avocat nirvāṇam nirvāṇam iti bhagavan ucyate
translated: Then the Bodhisattva Mahāmati again said this to the Blessed One: Blessed One, it is said 'nirvāṇa, nirvāṇa.'

analyzed: kasya etat bhagavan adhivacanam yat uta nirvāṇam iti
translated: Blessed One, what is the meaning of this word 'nirvāṇa'?

analyzed: bhagavān āha sarva vijñāna svabhāva vāsanā ālaya manaḥ manaḥ vijñāna dṛṣṭi vāsanā parāvṛttiḥ nirvāṇam iti ucyate sarva buddhaiḥ mayā ca nirvāṇa gati svabhāva śūnyatā vastu gocaram
translated: The Blessed One said: The complete transformation of the store-consciousness, mind, mental consciousness, and the tendencies of views, which is the nature of all consciousnesses, is called 'nirvāṇa' by all Buddhas and by me. The realm of nirvāṇa is the domain of emptiness, the nature of reality.

analyzed: punar aparam mahāmate nirvāṇam ārya jñāna pratyātma gati gocaram śāśvata uccheda vikalpa bhāva abhāva vivarjitam
translated: Moreover, Mahāmati, nirvāṇa is the domain of the noble wisdom that is realized within oneself, and it is free from the extremes of eternalism and nihilism.

analyzed: katham na śāśvatam
translated: How is it not eternal?

analyzed: yat uta sva sāmānya lakṣaṇa vikalpa prahīṇam
translated: Because it is free from the conceptualization of specific and general characteristics.

analyzed: atas na śāśvatam
translated: Therefore, it is not eternal.

original: tatrānucchedo yaduta sarvārthā atītānāgatapratyutpannāḥ pratyātmamapi gacchanti /
analyzed: tatra anucchedaḥ yat uta sarva arthāḥ atīta anāgata pratyutpannāḥ pratyātmam api gacchanti
translated: There is no annihilation because all objects, past, future, and present, are realized within oneself.

analyzed: atas na ucchedaḥ
translated: Therefore, there is no annihilation.

original: punarmahāmate mahāparinirvāṇaṃ na nāśo na maraṇam /
analyzed: punar mahāmate mahāparinirvāṇam na nāśaḥ na maraṇam
translated: Again, Mahāmati, great parinirvāṇa is neither destruction nor death.

original: yadi punarmahāmate mahāparinirvāṇaṃ maraṇaṃ syāt /🔽punarapi janmaprabandhaḥ syāt /
analyzed: yadi punar mahāmate mahāparinirvāṇam maraṇam syāt  punar api janma prabandhaḥ syāt
translated: If, again, Mahāmati, great parinirvāṇa were death,🔽then the continuum of birth would occur again.

analyzed: atha vināśaḥ syāt
translated: If it were destruction,

analyzed: saṃskṛta lakṣaṇa patitam syāt
translated: it would fall under the characteristics of the conditioned.

original: ata etasmātkāraṇānmahāmate mahāparinirvāṇaṃ na nāśaṃ na maraṇam /
analyzed: atas etasmāt kāraṇāt mahāmate mahāparinirvāṇam na nāśam na maraṇam
translated: For this reason, Mahāmati, great parinirvāṇa is neither destruction nor death.

analyzed: cyuti vigatam maraṇam adhigacchanti yoginaḥ
translated: Yogis attain death free from falling away.

analyzed: punar aparam mahāmate mahāparinirvāṇam aprahīṇa asaṃprāptitaḥ unuccheda aśāśvatataḥ na ekārthataḥ na anārthataḥ nirvāṇam iti ucyate
translated: Moreover, Mahāmati, great parinirvāṇa is said to be nirvāṇa because of neither abandoning nor attaining, neither annihilation nor eternalism, neither the same meaning nor different meanings.

analyzed: punar aparam mahāmate śrāvaka pratyekabuddhānām nirvāṇam sva sāmānya lakṣaṇa avabodhāt a saṃsargataḥ
translated: Moreover, Mahāmati, the nirvāṇa of śrāvakas and pratyekabuddhas is due to understanding their own and general characteristics, not associating,

analyzed: viṣaya aviparyāsa darśanāt vikalpaḥ na pravartate
translated: and not conceptualizing because of seeing the non-reversal of objects.

analyzed: tatas teṣām tatra nirvāṇa buddhiḥ bhavati
translated: Therefore, they have the notion of nirvāṇa there.

analyzed: punar aparam mahāmate dvi prakāram svabhāva dvaya lakṣaṇam bhavati
translated: Moreover, Mahāmati, there are two kinds of characteristics of the two natures.

analyzed: katamat dvi prakāram
translated: What are the two kinds?

analyzed: yat uta abhilāpa svabhāva abhiniveśataḥ ca vastu svabhāva abhiniveśataḥ ca
translated: Namely, attachment to the nature of verbal expression and attachment to the nature of objects.

analyzed: tatra mahāmate abhilāpa svabhāva abhiniveśaḥ na ādi kāla vāc prapañca vāsanā abhiniveśāt pravartate
translated: Among them, Mahāmati, attachment to the nature of verbal expression arises from attachment to the habitual tendencies of verbal proliferation since beginningless time.

analyzed: tatra vastu svabhāva abhiniveśaḥ punar mahāmate sva citta dṛśya mātra anavabodhāt pravartate
translated: Among them, Mahāmati, attachment to the nature of objects arises from the lack of understanding that what is seen is one's own mind.

original: punaraparaṃ mahāmate adhiṣṭhānadvayādhiṣṭhitā bodhisattvāstathāgatānāmarhatāṃ samyaksaṃbuddhānāṃ caraṇayornipatya praśnān paripṛcchanti /
analyzed: punar aparam mahāmate adhiṣṭhāna dvaya dhiṣṭhitāḥ bodhisattvāḥ tathāgatānām arhatām samyaksaṃbuddhānām caraṇayoḥ nipatya praśnān paripṛcchanti
translated: Moreover, Mahāmati, bodhisattvas who are empowered by the two bases fall at the feet of the Tathāgatas, the Arhats, the Perfectly Awakened Ones, and ask questions.

analyzed: katamena adhiṣṭhāna dvayena adhiṣṭhitāḥ
translated: By what two bases are they empowered?

analyzed: yat uta samādhi samāpatti adhiṣṭhānena sarva kāya mukha pāṇi abhiṣeka adhiṣṭhānena ca
translated: Namely, by the empowerment of meditative absorption and attainment, and by the empowerment of the consecration of the entire body, face, and hands.

original: tatra mahāmate bodhisattvā mahāsattvāḥ prathamāyāṃ bhūmau buddhādhiṣṭhānādhiṣṭhitā mahāyānaprabhāsaṃ nāma bodhisattvasamādhiṃ samāpadyante /
analyzed: tatra mahāmate bodhisattvāḥ mahāsattvāḥ prathamāyām bhūmau buddha adhiṣṭhāna dhiṣṭhitāḥ mahāyānaprabhāsam nāma bodhisattva samādhim samāpadyante
translated: There, Mahāmati, the bodhisattva-mahāsattvas in the first stage, empowered by the empowerment of the Buddhas, enter the bodhisattva samādhi called the Light of the Great Vehicle.

original: samanantarasamāpannānāṃ ca teṣāṃ bodhisattvānāṃ mahāsattvānāṃ mahāyānaprabhāsaṃ bodhisattvasamādhim /
analyzed: samanantara samāpannānām ca teṣām bodhisattvānām mahāsattvānām mahāyānaprabhāsam bodhisattva samādhim
translated: And as soon as those bodhisattva mahāsattvas had entered it, they attained the bodhisattva samādhi called the illumination of the Great Vehicle.

original: atha daśadiglokadhātuvyavasthitāstathāgatā arhantaḥ samyaksaṃbuddhā mukhānyupadarśya sarvakāyamukhavācāsaṃdarśanenādhiṣṭhānaṃ kurvanti /
analyzed: atha daśa diś lokadhātu vyavasthitāḥ tathāgatāḥ arhantaḥ samyaksaṃbuddhāḥ mukhāni upadarśya sarva kāya mukha vācā saṃdarśanena adhiṣṭhānam kurvanti
translated: Then the tathāgatas, arhats, perfectly enlightened buddhas abiding in the world systems of the ten directions revealed their faces and empowered them with the manifestation of their entire bodies, faces, and speech.

original: yathā mahāmate vajragarbhasya bodhisattvasya mahāsattvasya anyeṣāṃ ca tādṛglakṣaṇaguṇasamanvāgatānāṃ bodhisattvānāṃ mahāsattvānām /
analyzed: yathā mahāmate vajragarbhasya bodhisattvasya mahāsattvasya anyeṣām ca tādṛś lakṣaṇa guṇa samanvāgatānām bodhisattvānām mahāsattvānām
translated: Just as, Mahāmati, they did for the bodhisattva mahāsattva Vajragarbha and other bodhisattva mahāsattvas endowed with such characteristics and qualities.

original: evaṃ mahāmate prathamāyāṃ bhūmau bodhisattvā mahāsattvāḥ samādhisamāpattyadhiṣṭhānaṃ pratilabhante /
analyzed: evam mahāmate prathamāyām bhūmau bodhisattvāḥ mahāsattvāḥ samādhi samāpatti adhiṣṭhānam pratilabhante
translated: In the same way, Mahāmati, the bodhisattva mahāsattvas attain the empowerment of entering into samādhi on the first ground.

original: kalpaśatasahasraṃ saṃcitaiḥ kuśalamūlairanupūrveṇa bhūmipakṣavipakṣalakṣaṇagatiṃgatāṃ dharmameghāyāṃ bodhisattvabhūmau mahāpadmavimānāsanasthasya bodhisattvasya mahāsattvasya tadanurūpairbodhisattvairmahāsattvaiḥ parivṛtasya sarvaratnābharaṇavibhūṣitakirīṭasya haritālakanakacampakacandrāṃśumayūkhapadmasadṛśā daśadiglokadhātvāgatā jinakarāstasya bodhisattvasya mahāsattvasya padmavimānāsanasthasya mūrdhanyabhiṣiñcanti vaśavarticakravartīndrarājavatsarvakāyamukhapāṇyabhiṣekena sa ca bodhisattvaste ca bodhisattvāḥ pāṇyabhiṣekādhiṣṭhānādhiṣṭhitā ityucyante /
analyzed: kalpa śata sahasram saṃcitaiḥ kuśala mūlaiḥ anupūrveṇa bhūmi pakṣa vipakṣa lakṣaṇa gatiṃgatām dharmameghāyām bodhisattva bhūmau mahāpadma vimāna āsana sthasya bodhisattvasya mahāsattvasya tad anurūpaiḥ bodhisattvaiḥ mahāsattvaiḥ parivṛtasya sarva ratna ābharaṇa vibhūṣita kirīṭasya haritāla kanaka campaka candra aṃśu mayūkha padma sadṛśāḥ daśa diś lokadhātu āgatāḥ jina karāḥ tasya bodhisattvasya mahāsattvasya padma vimāna āsana sthasy
translated: With roots of virtue accumulated over a hundred thousand eons, gradually reaching the stage of the characteristics of the side of virtue and the side of demerit, on the Bodhisattva ground Cloud of Dharma, a Bodhisattva Mahasattva seated on a great lotus chariot, surrounded by Bodhisattva Mahasattvas of similar qualities, his crown adorned with all kinds of jewels, his hands like lotuses, the hands of the Victorious Ones from the worlds of the ten directions come and anoint the head of that Bodhisattva Mahasattva seated on the lotus chariot, like a universal monarch who has attained sovereignty anoints the entire body, face, and hands, and that Bodhisattva and those Bodhisattvas are called those who have received the consecration of the hands through the empowerment of the consecration of the hands.

analyzed: etat mahāmate bodhisattvānām mahāsattvānām adhiṣṭhāna dvayam
translated: This, Mahamati, is the two consecrations of the Bodhisattva Mahasattvas.

analyzed: yena adhiṣṭhāna dvayena adhiṣṭhitāḥ bodhisattvāḥ mahāsattvāḥ sarva buddha mukhāni avalokayanti
translated: By which two kinds of blessings, the Bodhisattva-Mahasattvas look at the faces of all Buddhas.

analyzed: anyatra a vyavalokyāḥ tathāgatāḥ arhantaḥ samyaksaṃbuddhāḥ
translated: Except for the Tathagatas, Arhats, Samyaksambuddhas who are not looked at.

original: punaraparaṃ mahāmate yatkiṃcidbodhisattvānāṃ mahāsattvānāṃ pratibhāti samādhyṛddhideśanākāreṇa /
analyzed: punar aparam mahāmate yat kiṃcid bodhisattvānām mahāsattvānām pratibhāti samādhi ṛddhi deśanā ākāreṇa
translated: Moreover, Mahamati, whatever the Bodhisattva-Mahasattvas conceive, in the form of teaching the accomplishment of samadhi,

analyzed: tat sarva buddha adhiṣṭhāna dvaya dhiṣṭhitānām
translated: that is due to the blessing of the two kinds of blessings from all Buddhas.

original: yadi punarmahāmate bodhisattvānāṃ mahāsattvānāmadhiṣṭhānamantareṇa pratibhānaṃ pratibhāyāt /
analyzed: yadi punar mahāmate bodhisattvānām mahāsattvānām adhiṣṭhānam antareṇa pratibhānam pratibhāyāt
translated: But if, Mahamati, the eloquence of the Bodhisattva-Mahasattvas were to appear without blessing,

analyzed: bāla pṛthagjanānām api mahāmate pratibhānam pratibhāyāt
translated: the eloquence of foolish ordinary people would also appear, Mahamati.

analyzed: tat kasya hetoḥ
translated: Why is that?

analyzed: yat uta adhiṣṭhāna an adhiṣṭhita tvāt
translated: Because of the lack of blessing.

original: tṛṇagulmavṛkṣaparvatā api mahāmate vividhāni ca vādyabhāṇḍāni nagarabhavanagṛhavimānāsanasthānāni tathāgatapraveśādhiṣṭhānena pravādyante /
analyzed: tṛṇa gulma vṛkṣa parvatāḥ api mahāmate vividhāni ca vādya bhāṇḍāni nagara bhavana gṛha vimāna āsana sthānāni tathāgata praveśa adhiṣṭhānena pravādyante
translated: Even grass, bushes, trees, and mountains, and various musical instruments, cities, houses, palaces, seats, and places, Mahamati, are played upon by the blessing of the Tathagata's entry.

original: kiṃ punarmahāmate sacetanā mūkāndhabadhirā api mahāmate svadoṣebhyo vimucyante /
analyzed: kim punar mahāmate sa cetanāḥ mūka andha badhirāḥ api mahāmate sva doṣebhyaḥ vimucyante
translated: So what to speak of sentient beings, Mahamati, the mute, blind, and deaf are also liberated from their own faults, Mahamati.

analyzed: evam mahā guṇa viśeṣam mahāmate tathāgata adhiṣṭhānam
translated: Thus, O Mahāmati, the Tathāgatas' blessing has great special qualities.

original: punaraparaṃ mahāmatirāhakiṃ punarbhagavaṃstathāgatā arhantaḥ samyaksaṃbuddhā bodhisattvānāṃ mahāsattvānāṃ samādhisamāpattyavasthānakāle viśeṣabhūmau ca abhiṣekādhiṣṭhānaṃ prakurvanti /
analyzed: punar aparam mahāmatiḥ āha kim punar bhagavan tathāgatāḥ arhantaḥ samyaksaṃbuddhāḥ bodhisattvānām mahāsattvānām samādhi samāpatti avasthāna kāle viśeṣa bhūmau ca abhiṣeka adhiṣṭhānam prakurvanti
translated: Moreover, Mahāmati said, Do the Tathāgatas, the Arhats, the Perfectly Awakened Ones, bless the Bodhisattva-Mahāsattvas when they are in the state of concentration and meditative absorption, and on the stage of distinction, with the consecration?

original: bhagavānāhamārakarmakleśaviyuktārthaṃ śrāvakadhyānabhūmyaprapatanatayā ca tathāgatabhūmipratyātmādhigamanatayā ca prāptadharmādhigamavivṛddhaye ca /
analyzed: bhagavān āha māra karma kleśa viyukta artham śrāvaka dhyāna bhūmi aprapatanatayā ca tathāgata bhūmi pratyātma adhigamanatayā ca prāpta dharma adhigama vivṛddhaye ca
translated: The Blessed One said, For the sake of being free from the karma and afflictions, so that they do not fall into the śrāvakas' stage of meditation, and so that they may personally realize the Tathāgata stage, and in order to increase the realization of the attained Dharma.

original: etena mahāmate kāraṇena tathāgatā arhantaḥ samyaksaṃbuddhā bodhisattvānāṃ mahāsattvānāmadhiṣṭhānairadhitiṣṭhanti /
analyzed: etena mahāmate kāraṇena tathāgatāḥ arhantaḥ samyaksaṃbuddhāḥ bodhisattvānām mahāsattvānām adhiṣṭhānaiḥ adhitiṣṭhanti
translated: For this reason, O Mahāmati, the Tathāgatas, the Arhats, the Perfectly Awakened Ones, bless the Bodhisattva-Mahāsattvas with their blessings.

original: anadhiṣṭhitāśca mahāmate bodhisattvā mahāsattvāḥ kutīrthyaśrāvakamārāśayapatitā nānuttarāṃ samyaksaṃbodhimabhisaṃbudhyeran /
analyzed: anadhiṣṭhitāḥ ca mahāmate bodhisattvāḥ mahāsattvāḥ kutīrthya śrāvaka māra āśaya patitāḥ na anuttarām samyaksaṃbodhim abhisaṃbudhyeran
translated: O Mahāmati, if the Bodhisattva-Mahāsattvas were not blessed, they would fall into the intentions of the non-Buddhist teachers, the śrāvakas, and Māra, and would not fully awaken to unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.

analyzed: atas tena kāraṇena bodhisattvāḥ mahāsattvāḥ tathāgataiḥ arhadbhiḥ samyaksaṃbuddhaiḥ anugṛhyante
translated: Therefore, for that reason, the Bodhisattva Mahasattvas are favored by the Tathagatas, the Arhats, the Perfectly Enlightened Ones.

analyzed: tatra idam ucyate
translated: Regarding this, it is said:

analyzed: adhiṣṭhānam narendrāṇām praṇidhānaiḥ viśodhitam
translated: The empowerment of the lords of men, purified by vows,

analyzed: abhiṣeka samādhi ādyāḥ prathamāt daśamāya vai
translated: The consecrations, samadhis, and so forth, from the first to the tenth,

original: atha khalu mahāmatirbodhisattvaḥ punarapi bhagavantametadavocatpratītyasamutpādaṃ punarbhagavatā deśayatā kāraṇavyapadeśa eva kṛto na svanayaprakṛtyavasthānakathā
analyzed: atha khalu mahāmatiḥ bodhisattvaḥ punar api bhagavantam etat avocat pratītyasamutpādam punar bhagavatā deśayatā kāraṇa vyapadeśaḥ eva kṛtaḥ na sva naya prakṛti avasthāna kathā
translated: Then the Bodhisattva Mahamathi again said this to the Blessed One: When the Blessed One taught dependent origination, he only explained the cause, not the discourse on the natural state of one's own way.

original: tīrthakarā api bhagavan kāraṇata utpattiṃ varṇayanti /
analyzed: tīrthakarāḥ api bhagavan kāraṇataḥ utpattim varṇayanti
translated: Blessed One, the non-Buddhists also describe arising from a cause.

analyzed: yat uta pradhāna īśvara puruṣa kāla aṇu pratyayebhyaḥ bhāvānām utpattayaḥ
translated: Namely, the arising of things from the conditions of Pradhana, Isvara, Purusha, time, and atoms.

analyzed: kim tu bhagavatā pratyaya paryāya antareṇa utpattiḥ varṇyate bhāvānām
translated: However, the Blessed One describes the arising of things through a different set of conditions.

original: na ca siddhāntaviśeṣāntaram /🔽sadasato hi bhagavaṃstīrthakarā apyutpattiṃ varṇayanti /
analyzed: na ca siddhānta viśeṣa antaram  sat asataḥ hi bhagavan tīrthakarāḥ api utpattim varṇayanti
translated: And there is no difference in the special tenets.🔽For the Blessed One, the non-Buddhists also describe arising from the existent and the non-existent.

analyzed: bhūtvā ca vināśam pratyayaiḥ bhāvānām
translated: And the destruction of things that have come to be through conditions.

analyzed: yat api uktam bhagavatā avidyā pratyayāḥ saṃskārāḥ yāvat jarā maraṇam iti
translated: And what was said by the Blessed One: 'The formations have ignorance as their condition, up to old age and death,'

analyzed: ahetu vāda vyapadeśaḥ eṣa bhagavatā anuvarṇitaḥ
translated: this is a teaching of the doctrine of no cause by the Blessed One.

analyzed: na sa hetuvādaḥ
translated: That is not the doctrine of cause.

analyzed: yugapad vayavasthitānām bhagavan etat bhavati asmin sati idam bhavati iti
translated: Blessed One, this is so for things that exist simultaneously, 'When this exists, that exists.'

analyzed: na krama vṛtti apekṣā avasthitānām
translated: Not for things that exist in a sequential process.

original: kiṃ tu tīrthakaravyapadeśa eva bhagavan viśiṣyate na tvadīyam /
analyzed: kim tu tīrthakara vyapadeśaḥ eva bhagavan viśiṣyate na tvadīyam
translated: But, Blessed One, only the teaching of the tīrthikas is distinguished, not yours.

analyzed: tat kasya hetoḥ
translated: What is the reason for that?

analyzed: tīrthakarāṇām him bhagavan kāraṇam apratītyasamutpannam kāryam abhinirvartayati
translated: For, Blessed One, the cause of the tīrthikas produces an effect that is not dependently arisen.

original: tava tu bhagavan kāraṇamapi kāryāpekṣaṃ kāryamapi kāraṇāpekṣam /
analyzed: tava tu bhagavan kāraṇam api kārya apekṣam kāryam api kāraṇa apekṣam
translated: But, Blessed One, the cause also depends on the effect, and the effect also depends on the cause.

analyzed: hetu pratyaya saṃkaraḥ ca evam anyonya anavasthā prasajyate
translated: And thus, Blessed One, there is a confusion of causes and conditions, and an infinite regress follows.

original: ahetutvaṃ ca bhagavan lokasyaasmin satīdaṃ bruvataḥ /
analyzed: ahetu tvam ca bhagavan lokasya asmin sati idam bruvataḥ
translated: And, Blessed One, if you say 'When this exists, that exists,' there is the fault of the world having no cause.

original: bhagavānāhana mahāmate mamāhetukakāraṇavādo hetupratyayasaṃkaraśca prasajyateasmin satīdaṃ bruvataḥ /
analyzed: bhagavān āha na mahāmate mama ahetuka kāraṇa vādaḥ hetu pratyaya saṃkaraḥ ca prasajyate asmin sati idam bruvataḥ
translated: The Blessed One said: 'Mahāmati, when I say When this exists, that exists, the fault of a confusion of causes and conditions and of the world having no cause does not follow for me.

analyzed: grāhya grāhaka abhāvāt
translated: Because of the non-existence of the grasped and the grasper.'

analyzed: sva citta dṛśya mātra avabodhāt
translated: Because of the understanding that [all phenomena] are merely appearances of one's own mind.

original: ye tu mahāmate grāhyagrāhakābhiniviṣṭāḥ svacittadṛśyamātraṃ nāvabudhyante bāhyasvaviṣayabhāvābhāvatvena /
analyzed: ye tu mahāmate grāhya grāhaka abhiniviṣṭāḥ sva citta dṛśya mātram na avabudhyante bāhya sva viṣaya bhāva abhāva tvena
translated: But those, Mahāmati, who are attached to the grasped and the grasper, who do not understand that [all phenomena] are merely appearances of one's own mind due to the non-existence of external objects and their own [mind],

analyzed: teṣām mahāmate eṣa doṣaḥ prasajyate
translated: for them, Mahāmati, this fault ensues.

analyzed: na tu mama pratītya kāraṇa vyapadeśam kurvataḥ
translated: But not for me, who teaches dependent origination as a cause.

analyzed: punar aparam mahāmatiḥ āha nanu bhagavan abhilāpa sadbhāvāt santi sarva bhāvāḥ
translated: Moreover, Mahāmati said, Blessed One, all things exist because of the existence of verbal expression.

analyzed: yadi punar bhagavan bhāvāḥ na syuḥ
translated: If, Blessed One, things did not exist,

analyzed: abhilāpaḥ na pravartate
translated: verbal expression would not occur.

analyzed: pravartate ca
translated: But it does occur.

analyzed: tasmāt abhilāpa sadbhāvāt bhagavan santi sarva bhāvāḥ
translated: Therefore, Blessed One, all things exist because of the existence of verbal expression.

analyzed: bhagavān āha asatām api mahāmate bhāvānām abhilāpaḥ kriyate
translated: The Blessed One said, Mahāmati, verbal expression is made even for non-existent things,

analyzed: yat uta śaśaviṣāṇa kūrma roma vandhyā putra ādīnām loke dṛṣṭaḥ abhilāpaḥ
translated: namely, the verbal expression of a rabbit's horns, a tortoise's hair, the son of a barren woman, and so on, is seen in the world.

original: te ca mahāmate na bhāvā nābhāvāḥ /
analyzed: te ca mahāmate na bhāvāḥ na abhāvāḥ
translated: And those, Mahāmati, are neither existent nor non-existent.

analyzed: abhilapyante ca
translated: They are expressed.

analyzed: tat yat avocaḥ tvam mahāmate abhilāpa sadbhāvāt santi sarva bhāvāḥ iti
translated: Therefore, Mahāmati, what you said - 'All things exist because of the existence of verbal expression' -

analyzed: sa hi vādaḥ prahīṇaḥ
translated: that statement is refuted.

analyzed: na ca mahāmate sarva buddhakṣetreṣu prasiddhaḥ abhilāpaḥ
translated: And, Mahāmati, the expression is not well-known in all Buddha-fields.

analyzed: abhilāpaḥ mahāmate kṛtakaḥ
translated: The expression, Mahāmati, is artificial.

analyzed: kvacid mahāmate buddhakṣetre nimiṣa prekṣayā dharmaḥ deśyate
translated: In some Buddha-fields, Mahāmati, the Dharma is taught by looking without blinking.

analyzed: kvacid iṅgitaiḥ  kvacid bhū vikṣepeṇa  kvacid netra saṃcāreṇa
translated: In some by gestures.🔽In some by shaking the earth.🔽In some by moving the eyes.

analyzed: kvacid āsyena  kvacid vijṛmbhitena
translated: In some by the face.🔽In some by yawning.

analyzed: kvacid utkāsana śabdena  kvacid kṣetra smṛtyā
translated: In some by the sound of coughing.🔽In some by the recollection of the field.

analyzed: kvacid spanditena
translated: In some by trembling.

original: yathā mahāmate animiṣāyāṃ gandhasugandhāyāṃ ca lokadhātau samantabhadrasya tathāgatasyārhataḥ samyaksaṃbuddhasya buddhakṣetre animiṣairnetraiḥ prekṣamāṇāste bodhisattvā mahāsattvā anutpattikadharmakṣāntiṃ pratilabhante anyāṃśca samādhiviśeṣān /
analyzed: yathā mahāmate animiṣāyām gandhasugandhāyām ca lokadhātau samantabhadrasya tathāgatasya arhataḥ samyaksaṃbuddhasya buddhakṣetre animiṣaiḥ netraiḥ prekṣamāṇāḥ te bodhisattvāḥ mahāsattvāḥ anutpattika dharma kṣāntim pratilabhante anyān ca samādhi viśeṣān
translated: As, Mahāmati, in the world-realms of Animiṣā and Gandhasugandhā of the Tathāgata Samantabhadra, the Perfectly Enlightened One, the Buddha-field, the Bodhisattva-Mahāsattvas, by looking with unblinking eyes, attain the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas and other special samādhis.

analyzed: atas eva asmāt kāraṇāt mahāmate na abhilāpa sadbhāvāt santi sarva bhāvāḥ
translated: For this reason, Mahāmati, all existents do not exist because of the existence of expressions.

analyzed: dṛṣṭam ca etat mahāmate
translated: And this, Mahāmati, is seen.

original: iha loke kṛmimakṣikaivamādyāḥ sattvaviśeṣā anabhilāpenaiva svakṛtyaṃ kurvanti //
analyzed: iha loke kṛmi makṣikā evamādyāḥ sattva viśeṣāḥ anabhilāpena eva sva kṛtyam kurvanti
translated: In this world, beings such as worms and flies accomplish their own tasks without any verbal expression.

analyzed: tatra idam ucyate
translated: Regarding that, this is said:

original: ākāśaṃ śaśaśṛṅgaṃ ca vandhyāyāḥ putra eva ca /
analyzed: ākāśam śaśa śṛṅgam ca vandhyāyāḥ putraḥ eva ca
translated: Space, the horn of a rabbit, and the son of a barren woman,

analyzed: asantaḥ hi abhilapyante tathā bhāveṣu kalpanā
translated: Are indeed non-existent, yet are verbally expressed. In the same way, conceptualization occurs regarding entities.

analyzed: hetu pratyaya sāmagryām bālāḥ kalpanti saṃbhavam
translated: Fools imagine arising from the totality of causes and conditions.

analyzed: a jānānāḥ nayam idam bhramanti tri bhava ālaye
translated: Not knowing this principle, they wander in the abode of the three realms.

original: atha khalu mahāmatirbodhisattvo mahāsattvaḥ punarapi bhagavantametadavocatnityaśabdaḥ punarbhagavan kvabhihitaḥ /
analyzed: atha khalu mahāmatiḥ bodhisattvaḥ mahāsattvaḥ punar api bhagavantam etat avocat nitya śabdaḥ punar bhagavan ku abhihitaḥ
translated: Then, the bodhisattva mahāsattva Mahamati again said this to the Blessed One: The word 'permanent,' Blessed One, where is it used?

analyzed: bhagavān āha bhrāntau mahāmate
translated: The Blessed One said: In error, Mahamati.

analyzed: yasmāt iyam bhrāntiḥ āryāṇām api khyāyate viparyāsataḥ
translated: Because this error appears even to the noble ones due to delusion.

analyzed: tat yathā mahāmate mṛgatṛṣṇā alāta cakra keśoṇḍuka gandharvanagara māyā svapna pratibimba akṣa puruṣāḥ loke vidvadbhiḥ viparyasyante
translated: For example, Mahamati, mirages, whirling fire-brands, optical illusions, gandharva cities, illusions, dreams, reflections, and apparitions are mistaken by the ignorant in the world,

analyzed: na tu vidvadbhiḥ
translated: but not by the wise.

analyzed: na ca punar na khyāyante
translated: And yet they do appear.

analyzed: sā punar bhrāntiḥ mahāmate aneka prakārā khyāyāt
translated: Moreover, Mahamati, that error appears in many ways.

analyzed: na bhrānteḥ aśāśvata tām kurute
translated: It does not make the error eternal.

analyzed: tat kasya hetoḥ
translated: What is the reason for that?

analyzed: yat uta bhāva abhāva vivarjita tvāt
translated: Namely, because it is devoid of existence and non-existence.

analyzed: katham punar mahāmate bhāva abhāva vivarjitā bhrāntiḥ
translated: But how, O Mahāmati, is error devoid of existence and non-existence?

analyzed: yat uta sarva bāla vicitra gocara tvāt samudra taraṃga gaṅgā udaka vat pretānām darśana a darśanataḥ
translated: Namely, because it is the domain of all the various childish ones, like the ocean waves and the Ganges water, due to being seen and not seen by ghosts.

analyzed: atas etasmāt kāraṇāt mahāmate bhrānti bhāvaḥ na bhavati
translated: For this reason, O Mahāmati, the existence of error does not occur.

analyzed: yasmāt ca tat udakam anyeṣām khyāyate
translated: And because that water appears to others,

analyzed: atas hi abhāvaḥ na bhavati
translated: therefore it is not non-existent.

analyzed: evam bhrāntiḥ āryāṇām viparyāsa aviparyāsa varjitā
translated: Thus, error is devoid of perversion and non-perversion for the noble ones.

analyzed: atas ca mahāmate asmāt kāraṇāt śāśvatā bhrāntiḥ yat uta nimitta lakṣaṇa abheda tvāt
translated: And for this reason, O Mahāmati, error is eternal, because of the non-difference of the characteristics of the cause.

original: na hi mahāmate bhrāntirvividhavicitranimittavikalpena vikalpyamānā bhedamupayāti /
analyzed: na hi mahāmate bhrāntiḥ vividha vicitra nimitta vikalpena vikalpyamānā bhedam upayāti
translated: For, O Mahāmati, error, when imagined by the various various causes and conceptual thoughts, does not become different.

analyzed: atas etasmāt kāraṇāt mahāmate bhrāntiḥ śāśvatā
translated: For this reason, O Mahāmati, error is eternal.

analyzed: katham punar mahāmate bhrāntiḥ tattvam bhavati
translated: But how, O Mahāmati, is error the truth?

original: yena punaḥ kāraṇena mahāmate āryāṇāmasyāṃ bhrāntau viparyāsabuddhirna pravartate /
analyzed: yena punar kāraṇena mahāmate āryāṇām asyām bhrāntau viparyāsa buddhiḥ na pravartate
translated: For what reason, O Mahāmati, does the idea of error not arise in the noble ones regarding this, nor the idea of non-error?

analyzed: na aviparyāsa buddhiḥ
translated: Not the idea of non-error.

original: nānyatra mahāmate āryā asyāṃ bhrāntau yakiṃcitsaṃjñino bhavanti nāryajñānavastusaṃjñinaḥ /
analyzed: na anyatra mahāmate āryāḥ asyām bhrāntau ya kiṃcid saṃjñinaḥ bhavanti na ārya jñāna vastu saṃjñinaḥ
translated: Apart from this, O Mahāmati, the noble ones do not have the idea of anything regarding this error, but have the idea of the object of noble knowledge.

analyzed: yat kiṃcid iti mahāmate bāla pralāpaḥ eṣa nārya pralāpaḥ
translated: O Mahāmati, anything is the prattle of fools, not the prattle of noble ones.

original: sā punarbhrāntirviparyāsāviparyāsena vikalpyamānā gotradvayāvahā bhavati yaduta āryagotrasya vā bālapṛthagjanagotrasya vā /
analyzed: sā punar bhrāntiḥ viparyāsa aviparyāsena vikalpyamānā gotra dvaya āvahā bhavati yat uta ārya gotrasya vā bāla pṛthagjana gotrasya vā
translated: And that error, when conceived as error and non-error, becomes the cause of two lineages, namely the noble lineage or the lineage of foolish ordinary beings.

analyzed: ārya gotram punar mahāmate tri prakāram upayāti yat uta śrāvaka pratyekabuddha buddha prabhedataḥ
translated: Moreover, O Mahāmati, the noble lineage proceeds in three ways, namely by the distinction of śrāvaka, pratyekabuddha, and buddha.

original: tatra kathaṃ punarmahāmate bālairbhrāntirvikalpyamānā śrāvakayānagotraṃ janayati /
analyzed: tatra katham punar mahāmate bālaiḥ bhrāntiḥ vikalpyamānā śrāvaka yāna gotram janayati
translated: How, O Mahāmati, does error, when conceived by fools, generate the lineage of the śrāvaka vehicle?

analyzed: yat uta mahāmate sva sāmānya lakṣaṇa abhiniveśena abhiniviśyamānā śrāvaka yāna gotrāya saṃvartate
translated: Namely, O Mahāmati, when it is conceived by attachment to the characteristics of its own and other things, it becomes conducive to the lineage of the śrāvaka vehicle.

original: evaṃ mahāmate sā bhrāntiḥ śrāvakayānagotrāvahā bhavati /
analyzed: evam mahāmate sā bhrāntiḥ śrāvaka yāna gotra āvahā bhavati
translated: Thus, O Mahāmati, that error becomes the cause of the lineage of the śrāvaka vehicle.

original: tatra kathaṃ punarmahāmate saiva bhrāntirvikalpyamānā pratyekabuddhayānagotrāvahā bhavati /
analyzed: tatra katham punar mahāmate sā eva bhrāntiḥ vikalpyamānā pratyekabuddha yāna gotra āvahā bhavati
translated: There, how is that very delusion, when conceptualized, the cause of the lineage of the Pratyekabuddha vehicle?

original: yaduta tasyā eva mahāmate bhrānteḥ svasāmānyalakṣaṇābhiniveśāsaṃsargataḥ pratyekabuddhayānagotrāvahā bhavati /
analyzed: yat uta tasyāḥ eva mahāmate bhrānteḥ sva sāmānya lakṣaṇa abhiniveśa a saṃsargataḥ pratyekabuddha yāna gotra āvahā bhavati
translated: It is because of that very delusion, Mahāmati, that by not associating with the attachment to the specific and general characteristics, it becomes the cause of the lineage of the Pratyekabuddha vehicle.

original: tatra kathaṃ punarmahāmate paṇḍitaiḥ saiva bhrāntirvikalpyamānā buddhayānagotrāvahā bhavati /
analyzed: tatra katham punar mahāmate paṇḍitaiḥ sā eva bhrāntiḥ vikalpyamānā buddha yāna gotra āvahā bhavati
translated: There, how is that very delusion, when conceptualized by the wise, the cause of the lineage of the Buddha vehicle?

analyzed: yat uta mahāmate sva citta dṛśya mātra avabodhāt bāhya bhāva abhāva vikalpana tayā vikalpyamānā buddha yāna gotrā avahā bhavati
translated: It is because, Mahāmati, by understanding that what is seen is one's own mind only, by not conceptualizing external existence or non-existence, when conceptualized, it becomes the cause of the lineage of the Buddha vehicle.

analyzed: atas eva mahāmate gotram
translated: For this very reason, Mahāmati, it is a lineage.

analyzed: eṣa gotra arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning of lineage.

analyzed: vicitra vastu bhāvanā punar mahāmate bālaiḥ bhrāntiḥ vikalpyamānā saṃsāra yāna gotra āvahā bhavati
translated: Again, Mahāmati, delusion, when conceptualized by the foolish as various things, becomes the cause of the lineage of the worldly vehicle.

analyzed: evam idam na anyathā iti
translated: This is so, not otherwise.

analyzed: atas etasmāt kāraṇāt mahāmate bhrāntiḥ vicitra vastu tvena kalpyate bālaiḥ
translated: For this reason, Mahāmati, delusion is conceptualized by the foolish as having various things.

analyzed: sā ca na vastu na avastu
translated: And that is neither a thing nor not a thing.

analyzed: sā eva mahāmate bhrāntiḥ a vikalpyamānā āryāṇām citta manaḥ manaḥ vijñāna dauṣṭhulya vāsanā svabhāva dharma parāvṛtti bhāvāt bhrāntiḥ āryāṇām tathatā iti ucyate
translated: That very delusion, O Mahāmati, when not conceptualized, is called the suchness of the noble ones, because of the transformation of the nature of the mind, thought, and consciousness of the noble ones, due to the habitual tendencies of the unruliness of the mind.

analyzed: atas etat uktam bhavati mahāmate tathatā api citta vinirmuktā iti
translated: Therefore, this is said: 'The suchness is also free from mind,' O Mahāmati.

original: asyaiva mahāmate padasyābhidyotanārthamidamuktaṃ mayākalpanaiśca vivarjitaṃ sarvakalpanāvirahitamiti yāvaduktaṃ bhavati //
analyzed: asya eva mahāmate padasya abhidyotana artham idam uktam mayā akalpanaiḥ ca vivarjitam sarva kalpanā virahitam iti yāvat uktam bhavati
translated: For the sake of illuminating this very term, O Mahāmati, this has been said by me: 'Free from imagination, devoid of all conceptualization,' up to this is said.

analyzed: mahāmatiḥ āha bhrāntiḥ bhagavan vidyate na iti
translated: Mahāmati said: 'Delusion exists, Blessed One, or does it not?'

analyzed: bhagavān āha māyā vat mahāmate na lakṣaṇa abhiniveśataḥ bhrāntiḥ vidyate
