analyzed: tat ucyatām bhagavan
translated: Please explain this, Blessed One.

analyzed: bhagavān āhana mahāmate yathā ruta artha grahaṇam kartavyam
translated: The Blessed One said, Mahamati, the meaning should be taken literally.

original: na ca mahāmate gaṅgānadīvālukāpramāṇatayā tryadhvakabuddhapramāṇatā bhavati /
analyzed: na ca mahāmate gaṅgā nadī vālukā pramāṇa tayā tri adhvaka buddha pramāṇa tā bhavati
translated: And, Mahamati, the measure of the Buddhas of the three times is not due to the measure of the sands of the Ganges river.

analyzed: tat kasya hetoḥ
translated: Why is that?

analyzed: yat uta loka atiśaya atikrānta tvāt mahāmate dṛṣṭāntaḥ udṛṣṭāntaḥ sadṛśa asadṛśa tvāt
translated: Because, Mahamati, the simile is not a simile, due to being similar and dissimilar, because it transcends the world.

original: na ca mahāmate tathāgatā arhantaḥ samyaksaṃbuddhāḥ sadṛśāsadṛśaṃ lokātiśayātikrāntaṃ dṛṣṭāntaṃ prāviṣkurvanti /
analyzed: na ca mahāmate tathāgatāḥ arhantaḥ samyaksaṃbuddhāḥ sadṛśa asadṛśam loka atiśaya atikrāntam dṛṣṭāntam prāviṣkurvanti
translated: And, Mahamati, the Tathagatas, Arhats, Samyak-Sambuddhas do not proclaim a simile that transcends the world, which is similar and dissimilar.

analyzed: anyatra upamā mātram etat mahāmate mayā upanyastam
translated: Except that, Mahamati, this is merely a simile that I have presented,

analyzed: taiḥ ca tathāgataiḥ
translated: and by those Tathagatas as well.

original: yathā gaṅgānadīvālukāsamāstathāgatā arhantaḥ samyaksaṃbuddhā iti nityānityābhiniveśābhiniviṣṭānāṃ bālapṛthagjanānāṃ tīrthakarāśayakudṛṣṭiyuktānāṃ saṃsārabhavacakrānusāriṇāmudvejanārthamkathamete udvignā bhavagaticakrasaṃkaṭādviśeṣārthino viśeṣamārabheranniti sulabhabuddhatvapradarśanārthaṃ na nodumbarapuṣpatulyastathāgatānāmutpāda iti kṛtvā vīryamārapsyante /
analyzed: yathā gaṅgā nadī vālukā samāḥ tathāgatāḥ arhantaḥ samyaksaṃbuddhāḥ iti nitya anitya abhiniveśa abhiniviṣṭānām bāla pṛthagjanānām tīrthakara āśaya kudṛṣṭi yuktānām saṃsāra bhava cakra anusāriṇām udvejana artham katham ete udvignāḥ bhava gati cakra saṃkaṭāt viśeṣa arthinaḥ viśeṣam ārabheran iti sulabha buddhatva pradarśana artham na na udumbara puṣpa tulyaḥ tathāgatānām utpādaḥ iti kṛtvā vīryam ārapsyante
translated: In order to frighten those foolish ordinary people who are attached to the notion of permanence and impermanence, who are endowed with the intentions and wrong views of the tīrthikas, who follow the cycle of existence and becoming, [the Buddha] said, The Tathāgatas, Arhats, Perfectly Awakened Ones are as rare as a flower on the udumbara tree. In order to show that Buddhahood is easy to attain, [the Buddha] said, The appearance of the Tathāgatas is not like the udumbara flower. Thus, they will strive with vigor.

original: deśanāpāṭhe tu mayā vaineyajanatāpekṣayā udumbarapuṣpasudurlabhaprādurbhāvāstathāgatā iti deśitam /
analyzed: deśanā pāṭhe tu mayā vaineya janatā apekṣayā udumbara puṣpa su durlabha prādurbhāvāḥ tathāgatāḥ iti deśitam
translated: But in the teaching recitation, I have taught, The Tathāgatas are as rare as the appearance of an udumbara flower, considering the disciples who are to be guided.

original: na ca mahāmate udumbarapuṣpaṃ kenaciddṛṣṭapūrvaṃ na drakṣyate /
analyzed: na ca mahāmate udumbara puṣpam kenacid dṛṣṭa pūrvam na drakṣyate
translated: O Mahāmati, the udumbara flower has never been seen by anyone before, nor will it be seen.

analyzed: tathāgatāḥ punar mahāmate loke dṛṣṭāḥ
translated: But, O Mahāmati, the Tathāgatas are seen in the world.

analyzed: dṛśyante ca etarhi
translated: And they are seen even now.

analyzed: na sva naya pratyavasthāna kathām adhikṛtya udumbara puṣpa su durlabha prādurbhāvāḥ tathāgatāḥ iti
translated: Not with reference to the discourse on the establishment of one's own doctrine, [the Buddha] said, The Tathāgatas are as rare as the appearance of an udumbara flower.

original: svanayapratyavasthānakathāyāṃ mahāmate nirdiśyamānāyāṃ lokātiśayātikrāntā dṛṣṭāntā yuktāḥ kriyante'śraddheyatvāt /
analyzed: sva naya pratyavasthāna kathāyām mahāmate nirdiśyamānāyām loka atiśaya atikrāntāḥ dṛṣṭāntāḥ yuktāḥ kriyante śraddheya tvāt
translated: In the teaching of the doctrine of the establishment of one's own understanding, O Mahāmati, when examples that transcend the world's marvels are being given, they are made to be appropriate due to the difficulty of believing them.

analyzed: aśraddheyam syāt bāla pṛthagjanānām ca
translated: It would be difficult to believe for foolish ordinary people.

analyzed: sva pratyātma ārya jñāna gocare na dṛṣṭāntāḥ na pravartante
translated: In the realm of one's own noble wisdom, examples do not apply.

analyzed: tattvam ca tathāgatāḥ
translated: The Tathāgatas are like that.

original: atasteṣu dṛṣṭāntā nopanyasyante //🔽kiṃ tu upamāmātrametanmahāmate kṛtaṃ yaduta gaṅgānadīvālukāsamāstathāgatāḥ samā na viṣamā akalpāvikalpanataḥ /
analyzed: atas teṣu dṛṣṭāntāḥ na upanyasyante  kim tu upamā mātram etat mahāmate kṛtam yat uta gaṅgā nadī vālukā samāḥ tathāgatāḥ samāḥ na viṣamāḥ akalpa avikalpanataḥ
translated: Therefore, examples are not applied to them.🔽However, O Mahāmati, this is merely a simile, namely, that the Tathāgatas are equal, not unequal, due to being free from conceptualization and discrimination, like the sands of the Ganges River.

original: tadyathā mahāmate gaṅgāyāṃ nadyāṃ vālukā mīnakacchapaśiśumāranakramahiṣasiṃhahastyādibhiḥ saṃkṣobhyamāṇā na kalpayanti na vikalpayantisaṃkṣobhyāmahe na veti nirvikalpāḥ svacchā malavyapetāḥ /
analyzed: tat yathā mahāmate gaṅgāyām nadyām vālukā mīnakacchapa śiśumāra nakra mahiṣa siṃha hasti ādibhiḥ saṃkṣobhyamāṇā na kalpayanti na vikalpayanti saṃkṣobhyāmahe na vā iti nirvikalpāḥ su acchāḥ mala vyapetāḥ
translated: Just as, O Mahāmati, the sands in the Ganges River, when agitated by fish, turtles, alligators, elephants, buffaloes, lions, and so on, do not conceptualize or discriminate, We are being agitated or We are not being agitated, being free from discrimination, clear, and free from defilement.

original: evameva mahāmate tathāgatānāmarhatāṃ samyaksaṃbuddhānāṃ svapratyātmāryajñānagaṅgāmahānadībalābhijñāvaśitāvālukāḥ sarvatīrthakarabālamīnaparapravādibhiḥ saṃkṣobhyamāṇā na kalpayanti na vikalpayanti /
analyzed: evam eva mahāmate tathāgatānām arhatām samyaksaṃbuddhānām sva pratyātma ārya jñāna gaṅgā mahānadī bala abhijñā vaśitā vālukāḥ sarva tīrthakara bāla mīna para pravādibhiḥ saṃkṣobhyamāṇāḥ na kalpayanti na vikalpayanti
translated: In the same way, Mahāmati, the Tathāgatas, the Saints, the Perfectly Enlightened Ones, whose sands of the great river of the Ganges of their own noble wisdom, powers, higher knowledges, and masteries, are not agitated by all the tīrthikas, fools, and opponents. They do not imagine, they do not conceptualize.

analyzed: tathāgata pūrva praṇihita tvāt sarva sukha samāpatti paripūryā sattvānām na kalpayanti na vikalpayanti
translated: Because of the Tathāgatas' previous vows, for the sake of fulfilling all beings' attainments of happiness, they do not imagine, they do not conceptualize.

analyzed: atas te gaṅgā nadī vālukā samāḥ tathāgatāḥ niḥ viśiṣṭāḥ anunaya pratigha apagata tvāt
translated: Therefore, those Tathāgatas, equal to the sands of the Ganges, are distinguished, being free from attachment and aversion.

original: tadyathā mahāmate gaṅgāyāṃ nadyāṃ vālukā pṛthivīlakṣaṇasvabhāvatvātpṛthivī /
analyzed: tat yathā mahāmate gaṅgāyām nadyām vālukā pṛthivī lakṣaṇa svabhāva tvāt pṛthivī
translated: Just as, Mahāmati, the sands in the Ganges River are earth, because of having the nature of the characteristic of earth.

analyzed: kalpa uddāhe dahyamānā api na pṛthivī svabhāvam vijahāti
translated: Even when being burned in the conflagration at the end of an eon, they do not abandon their nature as earth.

original: na ca mahāmate pṛthivī dahyate tejodhātupratibaddhatvādanyatra bālapṛthagjanā vitathatāpatitayā saṃtatyā dahyamānāṃ kalpayanti /
analyzed: na ca mahāmate pṛthivī dahyate tejaḥ dhātu pratibaddha tvāt anyatra bāla pṛthagjanāḥ vitatha tā patitayā saṃtatyā dahyamānām kalpayanti
translated: But, Mahāmati, the earth is not burned. Except that foolish ordinary beings, with a continuum fallen into error, imagine it to be burning, because it is bound to the fire element.

analyzed: na ca dahyate tad agni hetu bhūta tvāt
translated: But it is not burned, because it is the cause of fire.

analyzed: evam eva mahāmate tathāgatānām dharmakāyaḥ gaṅgā nadī vālukā samaḥ vināśī
translated: In the same way, O Mahāmati, the dharmakāya of the Tathāgatas is like the sands of the Ganges, imperishable.

original: tadyathā mahāmate nadyāṃ gaṅgāyāṃ vālukā apramāṇāḥ /
analyzed: tat yathā mahāmate nadyām gaṅgāyām vālukāḥ apramāṇāḥ
translated: Just as, O Mahāmati, the sands in the river Ganges are immeasurable,

original: evameva mahāmate tathāgatānāṃ raśmyāloko'pramāṇaḥ sattvaparipākasaṃcodanamupādāya sarvabuddhaparṣanmaṇḍaleṣu prasarpyate tathāgataiḥ /
analyzed: evam eva mahāmate tathāgatānām raśmyāloka upramāṇaḥ sattva paripāka saṃcodanam upādāya sarva buddha parṣad maṇḍaleṣu prasarpyate tathāgataiḥ
translated: in the same way, O Mahāmati, the light-rays of the Tathāgatas are immeasurable, for the sake of encouraging the spiritual development of beings, they spread out in all the assemblies of Buddhas.

original: tadyathā mahāmate gaṅgāyāṃ nadyāṃ vālukā na vālukāsvabhāvāntaramārabhante /
analyzed: tat yathā mahāmate gaṅgāyām nadyām vālukā na vālukā svabhāva antaram ārabhante
translated: Just as, O Mahāmati, the sands in the river Ganges do not give rise to any other nature than sand,

analyzed: vālukā avasthāḥ eva vālukāḥ
translated: they are only sands in their state as sands.

original: evameva mahāmate tathāgatānāmarhatāṃ samyaksaṃbuddhānāṃ saṃsāre na pravṛttirna nivṛttiḥ /
analyzed: evam eva mahāmate tathāgatānām arhatām samyaksaṃbuddhānām saṃsāre na pravṛttiḥ na nivṛttiḥ
translated: In the same way, O Mahāmati, the Tathāgatas, the Arhats, the Perfectly Enlightened Ones, do not engage in or turn away from the world.

analyzed: bhava pravṛtti ucchinna hetu tvāt
translated: Because the cause of engaging in existence is cut off.

original: tadyathā mahāmate gaṅgāyāṃ nadyāṃ vālukā apakṛṣṭā api na prajñāyante /
analyzed: tat yathā mahāmate gaṅgāyām nadyām vālukāḥ apakṛṣṭāḥ api na prajñāyante
translated: Just as, O Mahāmati, the sands in the river Ganges are not known even when removed,

analyzed: prakṣiptāḥ api na prajñāyante
translated: and are not known even when put in,

original: mahāmate evameva tathāgatānāṃ jñānaṃ sattvaparipākayogena na kṣīyate na vardhate /
analyzed: mahāmate evam eva tathāgatānām jñānam sattva paripāka yogena na kṣīyate na vardhate
translated: in the same way, O Mahāmati, the knowledge of the Tathāgatas does not diminish or increase through the yoga of the spiritual development of beings.

analyzed: aśarīra tvāt dharmasya
translated: Because the Dharma is without a body.

original: śarīravatāṃ hi mahāmate nāśo bhavati nāśarīravatām /
analyzed: śarīravatām hi mahāmate nāśaḥ bhavati na aśarīravatām
translated: For, O Mahāmati, the destruction of those who have bodies occurs, not of those who are bodiless.

analyzed: dharmaḥ ca aśarīraḥ
translated: And the Dharma is bodiless.

original: tadyathā mahāmate gaṅgāyāṃ nadyāṃ vālukā niṣpīḍyamānā ghṛtatailārthibhirghṛtatailādivirahitāḥ /
analyzed: tat yathā mahāmate gaṅgāyām nadyām vālukā niṣpīḍyamānā ghṛta taila arthibhiḥ ghṛta taila ādi virahitāḥ
translated: Just as, O Mahāmati, the sand in the river Ganges, when pressed by those seeking ghee and oil, is devoid of ghee, oil, and so on,

original: evameva mahāmate tathāgatāḥ sattvaduḥkhairniṣpīḍyamānā dharmadhātvīśvarapraṇidhānasukhaṃ na vijahati mahāmate mahākaruṇopetatvāt /
analyzed: evam eva mahāmate tathāgatāḥ sattva duḥkhaiḥ niṣpīḍyamānāḥ dharmadhātu īśvara praṇidhāna sukham na vijahati mahāmate mahā karuṇā upeta tvāt
translated: in the same way, O Mahāmati, the Tathāgatas, when pressed by the sufferings of beings, do not abandon the bliss of the lordly resolve in the dharmadhātu, O Mahāmati, because they are endowed with great compassion.

analyzed: yāvat sarva sattvāḥ na nirvāpyante tathāgataiḥ
translated: As long as all beings are not caused to attain nirvāṇa by the Tathāgatas,

original: tadyathā mahāmate gaṅgāyāṃ nadyāṃ vālukāḥ pravāhānukūlāḥ pravahanti nānudake /
analyzed: tat yathā mahāmate gaṅgāyām nadyām vālukāḥ pravāha anukūlāḥ pravahanti na anudake
translated: just as, O Mahāmati, the sand in the river Ganges, being favorable to the current, flows along with the current, not without water,

original: evameva mahāmate tathāgatānāṃ sarvabuddhadharmadeśanā nirvāṇapravāhānukūlā saṃvartate /
analyzed: evam eva mahāmate tathāgatānām sarva buddha dharma deśanā nirvāṇa pravāha anukūlā saṃvartate
translated: in the same way, O Mahāmati, the teaching of all the Buddha-dharmas of the Tathāgatas proceeds in accordance with the current of nirvāṇa.

analyzed: tena gaṅgā nadī vālukā samāḥ tathāgatāḥ iti ucyante
translated: Therefore, they are said to be equal to the sand in the river Ganges.

analyzed: na ayam mahāmate gati arthaḥ tathāgateṣu pravartate
translated: This, O Mahāmati, does not apply to the Tathāgatas in the sense of going.

analyzed: vināśaḥ mahāmate gati arthaḥ bhavati
translated: Destruction, O Mahāmati, is the meaning of going.

original: na ca mahāmate saṃsārasya pūrvā koṭiḥ prajñāyate /
analyzed: na ca mahāmate saṃsārasya pūrvā koṭiḥ prajñāyate
translated: And, O Mahāmati, the beginning of saṃsāra is not known.

analyzed: a prajñāyamānā katham gati arthena nirdekṣyāmi
translated: How can I explain it as having the meaning of going when it is not known?

analyzed: gati arthaḥ mahāmate ucchedaḥ
translated: The meaning of going, Mahāmati, is annihilation.

analyzed: na ca bāla pṛthagjanāḥ saṃprajānanti
translated: And the foolish ordinary people do not understand it.

original: mahāmatirāhatadyadi bhagavan pūrvā koṭirna prajñāyate sattvānāṃ saṃsaratām /
analyzed: mahāmatiḥ āha tat yadi bhagavan pūrvā koṭiḥ na prajñāyate sattvānām saṃsaratām
translated: Mahāmati said, If, Blessed One, the prior limit of sentient beings transmigrating is not known,

analyzed: tat katham mokṣaḥ prajñāyate prāṇinām
translated: How then is liberation known for living beings?

analyzed: bhagavān āha anādi kāla prapañca dauṣṭhulya vikalpa vāsanā hetu vinivṛttiḥ mahāmate sva citta dṛśya bāhya artha parijñānāt vikalpasya āśraya parāvṛttiḥ mahāmate mokṣaḥ na nāśaḥ
translated: The Blessed One said, The cessation of the cause of the latent tendencies of conceptualization due to the beginningless world's coarseness, Mahāmati, is liberation for living beings, not annihilation, through the complete understanding of one's own mind and external objects that are seen. The transformation of the basis, Mahāmati, is liberation, not destruction.

analyzed: atas na ananta kathā mahāmate kiṃcitkārī bhavati
translated: Therefore, Mahāmati, the discourse on infinity is not of any use.

analyzed: vikalpasya eva mahāmate paryāyaḥ ananta koṭiḥ iti  na ca atra vikalpāt anyat kiṃcid sattva antaram asti
translated: Mahāmati, the synonym for conceptualization is 'infinite ends.'

original: adhyātmaṃ vā bahirdhā vā parīkṣyamāṇaṃ buddhyā /
analyzed: adhyātmam vā bahirdhā vā parīkṣyamāṇam buddhyā
translated: And here, when examined with the intellect, there is nothing else whatsoever, either internally or externally, apart from conceptualization.

analyzed: jñāna jñeya viviktāḥ hi mahāmate sarva dharmāḥ
translated: Mahāmati, all phenomena are free from the knowledge and the knowable.

analyzed: anyatra sva citta vikalpa aparijñānāt vikalpaḥ pravartate
translated: Conceptualization arises from the incomplete understanding of one's own mind's conceptualization.

analyzed: tad avabodhāt nivartate
translated: It ceases through understanding that.

analyzed: tatra idam ucyate
translated: Regarding this, it is said:

analyzed: gaṅgāyām vālukā samān ye paśyanti vināyakān
translated: Those who see the Vināyakas equal to the sands in the Ganges,

analyzed: anāśa gati niṣṭhān vai te paśyanti tathāgatān
translated: Who have attained the state of fasting, they see the Tathāgatas.

analyzed: gaṅgāyām vālukāḥ yadvat sarva doṣaiḥ vivarjitāḥ
translated: Just as the sands in the Ganges are free from all faults,

analyzed: vāha anukūlāḥ nityāḥ ca tathā buddhasya buddhatā  /
translated: So is the Buddhahood of the Buddha, always favorable to the vehicle.

original: atha khalu mahāmatirbodhisattvo mahāsattvaḥ punarapi bhagavantametadavocatdeśayatu bhagavān /
analyzed: atha khalu mahāmatiḥ bodhisattvaḥ mahāsattvaḥ punar api bhagavantam etat avocat deśayatu bhagavān
translated: Then the bodhisattva mahāsattva Mahamati again said this to the Blessed One: May the Blessed One teach

original: deśayatu me sugatastathāgato'rhan samyaksaṃbuddhaḥ sarvadharmāṇāṃ kṣaṇabhaṅgaṃ bhedalakṣaṇaṃ caiṣām /
analyzed: deśayatu me sugataḥ tathāgataḥ orhan samyaksaṃbuddhaḥ sarva dharmāṇām kṣaṇa bhaṅgam bheda lakṣaṇam ca eṣām
translated: may the Tathāgata, Arhat, Perfectly Awakened One teach me the momentary breaking and the distinguishing characteristics of the division of all dharmas.

analyzed: tat katham bhagavan sarva dharmāḥ kṣaṇikāḥ
translated: How, Blessed One, are all dharmas momentary?

analyzed: bhagavān ahatena hi mahāmate śṛṇu
translated: The Blessed One said: Listen then, Mahamati,

analyzed: sādhu ca suṣṭhu ca manasikuru
translated: listen well and accurately, and pay attention.

analyzed: bhāṣiṣye iham te
translated: I will tell you.

original: sādhu bhagavanniti mahāmatirbodhisattvo mahāsattvo bhagavataḥ pratyaśrauṣīt /
analyzed: sādhu bhagavan iti mahāmatiḥ bodhisattvaḥ mahāsattvaḥ bhagavataḥ pratyaśrauṣīt
translated: Excellent, Blessed One, said the bodhisattva mahāsattva Mahamati, and listened to the Blessed One.

original: bhagavāṃstasyaitadavocatsarvadharmāḥ sarvadharmā iti mahāmate yaduta kuśalākuśalāḥ saṃskṛtāsaṃskṛtā laukikalokottarāḥ sāvadyānavadyāḥ sāsravānāsravā upāttānupāttāḥ /
analyzed: bhagavān tasya etat avocat sarva dharmāḥ sarva dharmāḥ iti mahāmate yat uta kuśala akuśalāḥ saṃskṛta asaṃskṛtāḥ laukika lokottarāḥ sāvadya anavadyāḥ sa āsrava anāsravāḥ upātta anupāttāḥ
translated: The Blessed One said to him, All dharmas, all dharmas, Mahamati, namely the wholesome and unwholesome, the conditioned and unconditioned, the mundane and supramundane, the blameworthy and blameless, the contaminated and uncontaminated, the appropriated and unappropriated,

analyzed: saṃkṣepeṇa mahāmate pañca upādāna skandhāḥ citta manaḥ manaḥ vijñāna vāsanā hetukāḥ citta manaḥ manaḥ vijñāna vāsanā puṣṭaiḥ bāla pṛthagjanaiḥ kuśala akuśalena parikalpyante
translated: in brief, Mahamati, the five appropriated aggregates, are the cause of the latent tendencies of mind, thought, and consciousness. The latent tendencies of mind, thought, and consciousness are nourished by foolish ordinary beings through the wholesome and unwholesome.

original: samādhisukhasamāpattayo mahāmate dṛṣṭadharmasukhavihārabhāvena āryāṇāṃ kuśalānāsravā ityucyante /
analyzed: samādhi sukha samāpattayaḥ mahāmate dṛṣṭadharma sukha vihāra bhāvena āryāṇām kuśala anāsravāḥ iti ucyante
translated: The attainments of the bliss of concentration, Mahamati, are said to be wholesome and uncontaminated for the noble ones in the sense of abiding in the bliss of the present Dharma.

analyzed: kuśala akuśalāḥ punar mahāmate yat uta aṣṭau vijñānāni
translated: Moreover, Mahamati, the wholesome and unwholesome are as follows: namely, the eight consciousnesses.

analyzed: katamāni aṣṭau
translated: What are the eight?

original: yaduta tathāgatagarbha ālayavijñānasaṃśabdito mano manovijñānaṃ ca pañca ca vijñānakāyāstīrthyānuvarṇitāḥ /
analyzed: yat uta tathāgata garbhaḥ ālayavijñāna saṃśabditaḥ manaḥ manaḥ vijñānam ca pañca ca vijñāna kāyāḥ tīrthya anuvarṇitāḥ
translated: Namely, the womb of the Tathagata, called the store consciousness, the mind, the mental consciousness, and the five groups of consciousnesses as described by the non-Buddhists.

original: tatra mahāmate pañca vijñānakāyā manovijñānasahitā kuśalākuśalakṣaṇaparaṃparābhedabhinnāḥ saṃtatiprabandhanābhinnaśarīrāḥ pravartamānāḥ pravartante
analyzed: tatra mahāmate pañca vijñānakāyāḥ manaḥ vijñāna sahitā kuśala akuśa lakṣaṇa paraṃparā bheda bhinnāḥ saṃtati prabandhana abhinna śarīrāḥ pravartamānāḥ pravartante
translated: There, Mahāmati, the five groups of consciousness, together with the mind consciousness, differentiated by the succession of characteristics of wholesome and unwholesome, with bodies that are not differentiated by the continuity of the series, function as they arise.

analyzed: pravṛtya ca vinaśyanti
translated: And having arisen, they perish.

analyzed: sva citta dṛśya anavabodhāt samanantara nirodhena at vijñānam pravartate
translated: Because of not understanding the objects seen by one's own mind, another consciousness arises immediately after cessation.

original: saṃsthānākṛtiviśeṣagrāhakaṃ manovijñānaṃ pañcabhirvijñānakāyaiḥ saha saṃprayuktaṃ pravartate kṣaṇakālānavasthāyi /
analyzed: saṃsthāna ākṛti viśeṣa grāhakam manaḥ vijñānam pañcabhiḥ vijñānakāyaiḥ saha saṃprayuktam pravartate kṣaṇa kāla anavasthāyi
translated: The mind consciousness, which apprehends specific shapes and forms, arises together with the five groups of consciousness, not remaining for a moment.

analyzed: tat kṣaṇikam iti vadāmi
translated: I say that is momentary.

original: kṣaṇikaṃ punarmahāmate ālayavijñānaṃ tathāgatagarbhasaṃśabditaṃ manaḥsahitaṃ pravṛttivijñānavāsanābhiḥ kṣaṇikamanāsravavāsanābhirakṣaṇikam /
analyzed: kṣaṇikam punar mahāmate ālayavijñānam tathāgata garbha saṃśabditam manaḥ sahitam pravṛtti vijñāna vāsanābhiḥ kṣaṇikam anāsrava vāsanābhiḥ akṣaṇikam
translated: Moreover, Mahāmati, the momentary ālaya consciousness, called the womb of the Tathāgatas, together with the mind, is momentary due to the imprints of the active consciousnesses, and non-momentary due to the imprints of the undefiled [dharmas].

original: na ca bālapṛthagjanā avabudhyante kṣaṇikavādābhiniviṣṭā kṣaṇikākṣaṇikatāmimāṃ sarvadharmāṇām /
analyzed: na ca bāla pṛthagjanāḥ avabudhyante kṣaṇika vāda abhiniviṣṭā kṣaṇika akṣaṇika tām imām sarva dharmāṇām
translated: But foolish ordinary people, attached to the doctrine of momentariness, do not understand this momentariness and non-momentariness of all dharmas.

analyzed: tad anavabodhāt uccheda dṛṣṭyā asaṃskṛtān api dharmān nāśayiṣyanti
translated: Because of not understanding that, through the view of annihilation, they will destroy even the unconditioned dharmas.

original: asaṃsāriṇo mahāmate pañca vijñānakāyā ananubhūtasukhaduḥkhā anirvāṇahetavaḥ /
analyzed: asaṃsāriṇaḥ mahāmate pañca vijñānakāyāḥ ananubhūta sukha duḥkhāḥ anirvāṇa hetavaḥ
translated: O Great Being, the five groups of consciousness, which are not subject to worldly existence, which do not experience pleasure and pain, and which are not the cause of nirvana, are not the Tathagatagarbha.

original: tathāgatagarbhaḥ punarmahāmate anubhūtasukhaduḥkhahetusahitaḥ pravartate nivartate ca catasṛbhirvāsanābhiḥ saṃmūrcchitaḥ /
analyzed: tathāgata garbhaḥ punar mahāmate anubhūta sukha duḥkha hetu sahitaḥ pravartate nivartate ca catasṛbhiḥ vāsanābhiḥ saṃmūrcchitaḥ
translated: But, O Great Being, the Tathagatagarbha, accompanied by the cause of experienced pleasure and pain, proceeds and ceases with the four latent tendencies.

analyzed: na ca bālāḥ avabudhyante kṣaṇika dṛṣṭi vikalpa vāsita matayaḥ
translated: And the ignorant do not understand, their minds perfumed by the discrimination of the view of momentariness.

original: punaraparaṃ mahāmate samadhāraṇaṃ kalpasthitāḥ suvarṇavajrajinadhātuprāptiviśeṣā abhaṅginaḥ /
analyzed: punar aparam mahāmate sama dhāraṇam kalpa sthitāḥ suvarṇa vajra jina dhātu prāpti viśeṣāḥ abhaṅginaḥ
translated: Moreover, O Great Being, gold, diamond, and the attainment of the Victor's essence, which endure for an eon, are indestructible.

analyzed: yadi punar mahāmate abhisamaya prāptiḥ kṣaṇikā syāt
translated: If, O Great Being, the attainment of realization were momentary,

analyzed: anārya tvam āryāṇām syāt
translated: the noble ones would be non-noble.

analyzed: na ca anārya tvam āryāṇām bhavati
translated: But the noble ones do not become non-noble.

original: suvarṇaṃ vajraṃ ca mahāmate samadhāraṇaṃ kalpasthitā api tulyamānā na hīyante na vardhante /
analyzed: suvarṇam vajram ca mahāmate sama dhāraṇam kalpa sthitāḥ api tulya mānāḥ na hīyante na vardhante
translated: O Great Being, gold and diamond, even when weighed for an eon, do not decrease or increase.

original: tatkathaṃ bālaiḥ kṣaṇikārthe vikalpyate ādhyātmikabāhyānāṃ sarvadharmāṇāmasaṃdhābhāṣyakuśalaiḥ /
analyzed: tat katham bālaiḥ kṣaṇika arthe vikalpyate ādhyātmika bāhyānām sarva dharmāṇām asaṃdhā bhāṣya kuśalaiḥ
translated: How then is it discriminated by the ignorant as momentary, those unskilled in the unexcelled speech regarding all internal and external phenomena?

original: punarapi mahāmatirāhayatpunaretaduktaṃ bhagavatāṣaṭpāramitāṃ paripūrya buddhatvamavāpyata iti /
analyzed: punar api mahāmatiḥ āhayat punar etat uktam bhagavatā ṣaṣ pāramitām paripūrya buddha tvam avāpyate iti
translated: Again, Mahāmati said, What the Blessed One has said again, that 'having fulfilled the six perfections, one attains Buddhahood,'

analyzed: tat katamāḥ tāḥ ṣaḍ pāramitāḥ
translated: what are those six perfections?

analyzed: katham ca paripūrim gacchanti
translated: And how do they become fulfilled?

analyzed: bhagavān āha trayaḥ ete mahāmate pāramitā bhedāḥ
translated: The Blessed One said, Mahāmati, these are the three kinds of distinctions in the perfections:

analyzed: katame trayaḥ
translated: What are the three?

analyzed: yat uta laukika lokottara lokottaratamāḥ
translated: Namely, the mundane, the supramundane, and the most supramundane.

analyzed: tatra mahāmate laukikyaḥ pāramitāḥ ātma ātmīya grāha abhiniveśa abhiniviṣṭāḥ
translated: Therein, Mahāmati, the mundane perfections are those that are attached to the clinging and fixation on the grasping of self and what belongs to self.

analyzed: anta dvaya grāhiṇaḥ vicitra bhava upapatti āyatana artham rūpa ādi viṣaya abhilāṣiṇaḥ dāna pāramitām paripūrayanti
translated: They are the grasping of the two extremes, and for the sake of various births and abodes, they desire the objects such as form and so forth, and they fulfill the perfection of generosity.

analyzed: evam śīla kṣānti vīrya dhyāna prajñāpāramitām mahāmate paripūrayanti bālāḥ
translated: Thus, Mahāmati, the fools fulfill the perfections of morality, patience, vigor, meditation, and wisdom.

analyzed: abhijñāḥ ca abhinirharanti brahmatvāya
translated: And they manifest the superknowledges for the sake of becoming Brahmā.

original: tatra lokottarābhiḥ pāramitābhiḥ śrāvakapratyekabuddhā nirvāṇagrāhapatitāśayā dānādiṣu prayujyante yathaiva bālā ātmasukhanirvāṇābhilāṣiṇaḥ
analyzed: tatra lokottarābhiḥ pāramitābhiḥ śrāvaka pratyekabuddhāḥ nirvāṇa grāha patita āśayāḥ dāna ādiṣu prayujyante yathā eva bālāḥ ātma sukha nirvāṇa abhilāṣiṇaḥ
translated: Therein, with the supramundane perfections, the śrāvakas and pratyekabuddhas, with the intention that has fallen into the grasping of nirvāṇa, they apply themselves to generosity and so forth, just as the fools, who desire their own happiness and nirvāṇa,

original: lokottaratamāḥ punarmahāmate svacittadṛśyavikalpamātragrahaṇātsvacittadvayāvabodhādapravṛttervikalpasya upādānagrahaṇābhāvātsvacittarūpalakṣaṇānabhiniveśāddānapāramitā sarvasattvahitasukhārthamājāyate bodhisattvānāṃ mahāsattvānāṃ paramayogayoginām /
analyzed: lokottaratamāḥ punar mahāmate sva citta dṛśya vikalpa mātra grahaṇāt sva citta dvaya avabodhāt apravṛtteḥ vikalpasya upādāna grahaṇa abhāvāt sva citta rūpa lakṣaṇa anabhiniveśāt dāna pāramitā sarva sattva hita sukha artham ājāyate bodhisattvānām mahāsattvānām parama yoga yoginām
translated: Again, O Mahāmati, the supreme supramundane [pāramitā] arises for the bodhisattva-mahāsattvas, the supreme yogis, for the sake of the benefit and happiness of all beings, from the realization that what is seen is one's own mind only, from the understanding of one's own mind as twofold, from the non-arising of conceptualization, from the absence of grasping and clinging, and from non-attachment to the characteristics of one's own mind and form.

analyzed: yat tatra eva ālambane vikalpasya apravṛttim śīlayanti
translated: That is, they cultivate the non-arising of conceptualization right there on the object.

analyzed: tad śīlam pāramitā ca sā
translated: That is morality and that is the pāramitā.

analyzed: yā tasya eva vikalpasya apravṛtti kṣamaṇa tā grāhya grāhaka parijñayā  sā kṣānti pāramitā
translated: The forbearance pāramitā is the ability to forbear the non-arising of just that conceptualization through the thorough knowledge of the grasped and the grasper.

original: yena vīryeṇa pūrvarātrāpararātraṃ ghaṭate yogānukūladarśanādvikalpasya vyāvṛtteḥ /🔽sā vīryapāramitā /
analyzed: yena vīryeṇa pūrvarātra apararātram ghaṭate yoga anukūla darśanāt vikalpasya vyāvṛtteḥ  sā vīrya pāramitā
translated: The vigor pāramitā is the vigor by which one strives in the first and last watches of the night, because the turning away of conceptualization is conducive to yoga.🔽The meditation pāramitā is the meditation by which one attains the non-arising of conceptualization.

analyzed: yat vikalpa nivṛtteḥ tīrthya nirvāṇa grāha āpatanam sā dhyāna pāramitā
translated: The wisdom pāramitā is the wisdom by which one does not fall into the grasping of the nirvāṇa of the tīrthikas due to the cessation of conceptualization.

original: tatra prajñāpāramitā yadā svacittavikalpābhāvādābuddhipravicayātprativicinvan antadvaye na patati āśrayaparāvṛttipūrvakarmavināśataḥ /
analyzed: tatra prajñāpāramitā yadā sva citta vikalpa abhāvāt ā buddhi pravicayāt prativicinvan anta dvaye na patati āśraya parāvṛtti pūrva karma vināśataḥ
translated: There, the perfection of wisdom is when, due to the absence of conceptualization in one's own mind, one does not fall into the two extremes by discriminating without discriminating the non-arisen mind.

analyzed: sva pratyātma ārya gati pratilambhāya prayujyate
translated: It is applied for the attainment of the noble realization of one's own true nature.

analyzed: sā prajñāpāramitā
translated: That is the perfection of wisdom.

analyzed: etāḥ mahāmate pāramitāḥ
translated: These, O Mahāmati, are the perfections.

analyzed: eṣa pāramitā arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning of the perfections.

analyzed: tatra idam ucyate
translated: Regarding this, it is said:

analyzed: śūnyam anityam kṣaṇikam bālāḥ kalpenti saṃskṛtam
translated: The foolish conceive the conditioned as empty, impermanent, and momentary.

original: nadīdīpabījadṛṣṭāntaiḥ kṣaṇikārtho vikalpyate // //🔽nirvyāpāraṃ kṣaṇikaṃ viviktaṃ kṣayavarjitam /
analyzed: nadī dīpa bīja dṛṣṭāntaiḥ kṣaṇika arthaḥ vikalpyate  nirvyāpāram kṣaṇikam viviktam kṣaya varjitam
translated: The meaning of momentariness is discriminated by the examples of a river, a lamp, and a seed.

analyzed: anutpattiḥ ca dharmāṇām kṣaṇika artham vadāmi aham
translated: I declare the meaning of momentariness to be that which is without activity, momentary, secluded, and free from destruction, and the non-arising of phenomena.

original: utpattyanantaraṃ bhaṅgaṃ na vai deśemi bāliśān /
analyzed: utpatti anantaram bhaṅgam na vai deśemi bāliśān
translated: I do not teach to the foolish that there is destruction immediately after arising.

analyzed: nairantaryeṇa bhāvānām vikalpaḥ spandate gatau
translated: The conceptualization of things proceeds uninterruptedly in the course of their going.

original: sā vidyā kāraṇaṃ teṣāṃ cittānāṃ saṃpravartikam /
analyzed: sā vidyā kāraṇam teṣām cittānām saṃpravartikam
translated: That is the cause of those minds, which sets them in motion.

analyzed: antarā kim avasthā asau yāvat rūpam na jāyate
translated: What is the state in between, as long as form does not arise?

analyzed: samanantara pradhvastam cittam anyat pravartate
translated: Another mind arises immediately after the mind that has just ceased.

original: rūpaṃ na tiṣṭhate kāle kimālambya pravartsyate // //
analyzed: rūpam na tiṣṭhate kāle kim ālambya pravartsyate
translated: Form does not abide for a moment, what will it rely on to function?

analyzed: yasmāt yatra pravartate cittam vitatha hetukam
translated: Because the mind functions with false causes wherever it arises,

analyzed: na prasiddham katham tasya kṣaṇa bhaṅgā uvadhāryate
translated: How can the momentariness of that which is not established be ascertained?

analyzed: yoginām hi samāpattiḥ suvarṇam jina dhātavaḥ
translated: For yogis, the attainment, gold, the relics of the Victorious Ones,

analyzed: ābhāsvara vimānāḥ ca abhedyāḥ loka kāraṇāt
translated: And the celestial palaces of the Abhasvara gods are indestructible due to the cause of the world.

analyzed: sthitayaḥ prāpti dharmāḥ ca buddhānām jñāna saṃpadaḥ
translated: The abodes, the attainment of the Dharma, the wealth of knowledge of the Buddhas,

analyzed: bhikṣu tvam samaya prāptiḥ dṛṣṭāḥ vai kṣaṇikāḥ katham
translated: The state of being a monk, the attainment of the occasion - how are these seen to be momentary?

original: gandharvapuramāyādyā rūpā vai kṣaṇikā na kim /
analyzed: gandharva pura māyā ādyāḥ rūpāḥ vai kṣaṇikāḥ na kim
translated: Are the forms such as the city of gandharvas and illusions not momentary?

analyzed: abhūtikāḥ ca bhūtāḥ ca bhūtāḥ kecid kara āgatāḥ
translated: And some are non-existent, some are existent, some are present in the elements.

analyzed: iti laṅkāvatāre kṣaṇika parivartaḥ ṣaṣṭhaḥ
translated: Thus ends the sixth chapter on momentariness in the Lankavatara Sutra.

analyzed: nairmāṇikaparivartaḥ nāma saptamaḥ
translated: Chapter Seven, named Nirmanika.

original: atha khalu mahāmatirbodhisattvo mahāsattvaḥ punarapi bhagavantametadavocatarhantaḥ punarbhagavatā vyākṛtā anuttarāyāṃ samyaksaṃbodhau /
analyzed: atha khalu mahāmatiḥ bodhisattvaḥ mahāsattvaḥ punar api bhagavantam etat avocat arhantaḥ punar bhagavatā vyākṛtāḥ anuttarāyām samyaksaṃbodhau
translated: Then the Bodhisattva Mahasattva Mahamathi again said this to the Blessed One: Well now, those who have been prophesied by the Blessed One to be unsurpassed perfect complete enlightenment,

analyzed: a parinirvāṇa dharmakāḥ ca sattvāḥ tathāgata tve
translated: and those beings who have the Dharma of non-nirvana in the state of Tathagata,

original: yasyāṃ ca rātrau tathāgato'nuttarāṃ samyaksaṃbodhimabhisaṃbuddho yasyāṃ ca rātrau parinirvṛtaḥ /
analyzed: yasyām ca rātrau tathāgataḥ unuttarām samyaksaṃbodhim abhisaṃbuddhaḥ yasyām ca rātrau parinirvṛtaḥ
translated: And on the night when the Tathāgata attained supreme perfect enlightenment, and on the night when he passed into parinirvāṇa,

original: etasminnantare bhagavatā ekamapyakṣaraṃ nodāhṛtaṃ na pravyāhṛtam /
analyzed: etasmin antare bhagavatā ekam api akṣaram na udāhṛtam na pravyāhṛtam
translated: in between those two times, not a single syllable was uttered or spoken by the Blessed One.

original: sadā samāhitāśca tathāgatā na vitarkayanti na vyavacārayanti /
analyzed: sadā samāhitāḥ ca tathāgatāḥ na vitarkayanti na vyavacārayanti
translated: The Tathāgatas are always in samādhi, they do not think or ponder.

analyzed: nirmāṇāni ca nirmāya taiḥ tathāgata kṛtyam kurvanti
translated: Having created emanations, they perform the activities of a Tathāgata through them.

original: kiṃ kāraṇaṃ ca vijñānānāṃ kṣaṇaparaṃparābhedalakṣaṇaṃ nirdiśyate /
analyzed: kim kāraṇam ca vijñānānām kṣaṇa paraṃparā bheda lakṣaṇam nirdiśyate
translated: For what reason is the characteristic of the distinction of the succession of moments of consciousnesses taught?

analyzed: vajrapāṇiḥ ca satata samitam nitya anubaddhaḥ
translated: And Vajrapāṇi is always and constantly attached.

analyzed: pūrvā ca koṭiḥ na prajñāyate
translated: And the eastern limit is not known.

analyzed: nirvṛtiḥ ca prajñāpyate
translated: And nirvāṇa is known.

analyzed: mārāḥ ca māra karmāṇi ca karma plotayaḥ ca
translated: And Māras and the deeds of Māras and the entanglements of karma.

original: cañcāmāṇavikā sundarikā pravrājikā yathā dhautapātrādīni ca bhagavan karmāvaraṇāni dṛśyante /
analyzed: cañcā māṇavikā sundarikā pravrājikā yathā dhauta pātra ādīni ca bhagavan karma āvaraṇāni dṛśyante
translated: And Cañcā the young girl, Sundarī the nun, and the Blessed One's karmic obscurations such as the washed bowl are seen.

analyzed: tat katham bhagavatā sarva ākārajña tā prāptā a prahīṇaiḥ doṣaiḥ
translated: So how is it that the Blessed One attained omniscience without having abandoned faults?

analyzed: bhagavān ahatena hi mahāmate śṛṇu
translated: The Blessed One said: Listen, Mahāmati!

analyzed: sādhu ca suṣṭhu ca manasikuru
translated: Listen well and pay attention.

analyzed: bhāṣiṣye iham te
translated: I will teach it to you.

original: sādhu bhagavanniti mahāmatirbodhisattvo mahāsattvo bhagavataḥ pratyaśrauṣīt /
analyzed: sādhu bhagavan iti mahāmatiḥ bodhisattvaḥ mahāsattvaḥ bhagavataḥ pratyaśrauṣīt
translated: The bodhisattva mahāsattva Mahāmati said, Excellent, Blessed One! and listened as instructed.

original: bhagavāṃstasyaitadavocatnirupadhiśeṣaṃ nirvāṇadhātuṃ saṃdhāya bodhisattvacaryāṃ ca caritavatāṃ protsāhanārtham /
analyzed: bhagavān tasya etat avocat nirupadhi śeṣam nirvāṇa dhātum saṃdhāya bodhisattva caryām ca caritavatām protsāhana artham
translated: The Blessed One said this to him: With the nirvāṇa realm without remainder in mind, and in order to encourage those who have practiced the bodhisattva conduct.

original: santi hi mahāmate bodhisattvacaryācāriṇaḥ iha anyeṣu ca buddhakṣetreṣu /
analyzed: santi hi mahāmate bodhisattva caryā cāriṇaḥ iha anyeṣu ca buddhakṣetreṣu
translated: There are, O Mahāmati, bodhisattvas who practice the bodhisattva conduct in this and other buddha-fields.

original: yeṣāṃ śrāvakayānanirvāṇābhilāṣasteṣāṃ śrāvakayānarucivyāvartanārthaṃ mahāyānagatiprotsāhanārthaṃ ca tannirmitaśrāvakānnirmāṇakāyairvyākaroti /
analyzed: yeṣām śrāvaka yāna nirvāṇa abhilāṣaḥ teṣām śrāvaka yāna ruci vyāvartana artham mahāyāna gati protsāhana artham ca tat nirmita śrāvakān nirmāṇa kāyaiḥ vyākaroti
translated: For those who desire the nirvāṇa of the śrāvaka vehicle, in order to turn them away from their fondness for the śrāvaka vehicle and to encourage them in the path of the Great Vehicle, he proclaims those emanated śrāvakas with his emanated body.

analyzed: na ca dharmatā buddhaiḥ
translated: But not with the buddhas who are of the nature of reality.

analyzed: etat saṃdhāya mahāmate śrāvaka vyākaraṇam nirdiṣṭam
translated: With this in mind, O Mahāmati, the proclamation of the śrāvakas is taught.

original: na hi mahāmate śrāvakapratyekabuddhānāṃ kleśāvaraṇaprahāṇaviśeṣo vimuktyekarasatayā /
analyzed: na hi mahāmate śrāvaka pratyekabuddhānām kleśa āvaraṇa prahāṇa viśeṣaḥ vimukti ekarasa tayā
translated: For, O Mahāmati, the śrāvakas and pratyekabuddhas have no special abandonment of the afflictive obstructions, due to the single taste of liberation.

analyzed: na atra jñeya āvaraṇa prahāṇam
translated: Here there is no abandonment of the obstructions to the knowable.

analyzed: jñeya āvaraṇam punar mahāmate dharma nairātmya darśana viśeṣāt viśudhyate
translated: The obstructions to the knowable, O Mahāmati, are purified by the special insight into the selflessness of phenomena.

analyzed: kleśa āvaraṇam tu pudgala nairātmya darśana abhyāsa pūrvakam prahīyate
translated: But the obscuration of afflictions is abandoned through the practice of seeing the selflessness of persons.

analyzed: manaḥ vijñāna nivṛtteḥ
translated: Because the mental consciousness ceases.

analyzed: dharma āvaraṇa vinirmuktiḥ punar ālayavijñāna vāsanā vinivṛtteḥ viśudhyati
translated: And the liberation from the obscuration of phenomena is purified through the cessation of the imprints in the store consciousness.

original: pūrvadharmasthititāṃ saṃdhāya apūrvacaramasya cābhāvātpūrvaprahiṇairevākṣaraistathāgato na vitarkya na vicārya dharmaṃ deśayati /
analyzed: pūrva dharma sthiti tām saṃdhāya apūrva caramasya ca abhāvāt pūrva prahiṇaiḥ eva akṣaraiḥ tathāgataḥ na vitarkya na vicārya dharmam deśayati
translated: With reference to the previous state of phenomena, and because there is no previous or final [existence], the Tathāgata teaches the Dharma with the same words as before, without deliberation or reflection.

analyzed: saṃprajāna kāri tvāt amuṣita smṛti tvāt ca na vitarkayati na vicārayati
translated: Because of acting with full awareness and because of not losing mindfulness, he does not deliberate or reflect.

analyzed: catur vāsanā bhūmi prahīṇa tvāt cyuti dvaya vigamāt kleśa jñeya āvaraṇa dvaya prahāṇāt ca
translated: And because he has abandoned the four grounds of desire, because he is free from the two kinds of death, and because he has abandoned the two obscurations of afflictions and the knowable.

original: sapta mahāmate manomanovijñānacakṣurvijñānādayaḥ kṣaṇikāḥ vāsanāhetutvātkuśalānāsravapakṣarahitāḥ na saṃsāriṇaḥ /
analyzed: sapta mahāmate manaḥ manaḥ vijñāna cakṣuḥ vijñāna ādayaḥ kṣaṇikāḥ vāsanā hetu tvāt kuśala anāsrava pakṣa rahitāḥ na saṃsāriṇaḥ
translated: The mind, mental consciousness, eye consciousness, and so forth, O Mahāmati, are momentary, because they are the cause of imprints, they are devoid of the wholesome and uncontaminated factors, and they are not in saṃsāra.

analyzed: tathāgata garbhaḥ punar mahāmate saṃsarati nirvāṇa sukha duḥkha hetukaḥ
translated: But, O Mahāmati, the Tathāgatagarbha transmigrates, being the cause of the happiness and suffering of nirvāṇa.

analyzed: na ca bāla pṛthagjanāḥ avabudhyante śūnyatā vikṣipta matayaḥ
translated: But childish ordinary beings do not understand, their minds distracted by emptiness.

original: nirmitanairmāṇikānāṃ mahāmate tathāgatānāṃ vajrapāṇiḥ pārśvānugato na maulānāṃ tathāgatānāmarhatāṃ samyaksaṃbuddhānām /
analyzed: nirmita nairmāṇikānām mahāmate tathāgatānām vajrapāṇiḥ pārśva anugataḥ na maulānām tathāgatānām arhatām samyaksaṃbuddhānām
translated: The Vajra-holder attends only to the Emanation-Emanated Tathagatas, O Mahamathi, and not to the Original Tathagatas, the Arhats, the Fully Enlightened Ones.

original: maulo hi mahāmate tathāgataḥ sarvapramāṇendriyavinivṛttaḥ sarvabālaśrāvakapratyekabuddhatīrthyānām /
analyzed: maulaḥ hi mahāmate tathāgataḥ sarva pramāṇa indriya vinivṛttaḥ sarva bāla śrāvaka pratyekabuddha tīrthyānām
translated: For the Original Tathāgata, O Mahamathi, is beyond all means of knowledge, beyond all faculties, beyond all childish, Śrāvaka, Pratyekabuddha, and Tīrthika [views].

analyzed: dṛṣṭadharma sukha vihāriṇaḥ tam āgacchanti abhisamaya dharma jñāna kṣāntyā
translated: He dwells in the bliss of the present Dharma, and they approach him with the forbearance of the knowledge of the Dharma of realization.

analyzed: atas vajra pāṇiḥ tān na anubadhnāti
translated: Therefore, the Vajra-holder does not follow them.

analyzed: sarve hi nirmita buddhāḥ na karma prabhavāḥ
translated: For all the Emanation Buddhas are not born from karma.

original: na teṣu tathāgato na cānyatra tebhyastathāgataḥ /
analyzed: na teṣu tathāgataḥ na ca anyatra tebhyaḥ tathāgataḥ
translated: The Tathāgata is not in them, nor is the Tathāgata apart from them.

analyzed: kumbhakāra ālambana ādi prayogeṇa iva sattva kṛtyāni karoti
translated: He performs the duties of beings by means of the application of the potter's wheel, and so on.

analyzed: lakṣaṇa upetam ca deśayati
translated: And he teaches what is endowed with characteristics.

analyzed: na tu sva naya pratyavasthāna kathām sva pratyātma ārya gati gocaram
translated: But not the discourse on the establishment of one's own doctrine, which is the domain of one's own noble realization.

original: punaraparaṃ mahāmate ṣaṇṇāṃ vijñānakāyānāṃ nirodhāducchedadṛṣṭimāśrayanti bālapṛthagjanāḥ /
analyzed: punar aparam mahāmate ṣaṇṇām vijñānakāyānām nirodhāt uccheda dṛṣṭim āśrayanti bāla pṛthagjanāḥ
translated: Moreover, O Mahamathi, the foolish and ordinary people, due to the cessation of the six groups of consciousness, rely on the view of annihilation.

analyzed: ālaya anavabodhāt śāśvata dṛṣṭayaḥ bhavanti
translated: Due to not understanding the storehouse, they have the view of eternalism.

analyzed: sva mati vikalpasya mahāmate pūrvā koṭiḥ na prajñāyate
translated: The beginning point of one's own mental conceptualization is not known, O Mahāmati.

analyzed: sva mati vikalpasya eva vinivṛtteḥ mokṣaḥ prajñāyate
translated: Liberation is known when one's own mental conceptualization ceases.

analyzed: catur vāsanā prahāṇāt sarva doṣa prahāṇam
translated: By abandoning the four latent tendencies, all faults are abandoned.

analyzed: tatra idam ucyate
translated: Regarding this, it is said:

original: trīṇi yānānyayānaṃ ca buddhānāṃ nāsti nirvṛtiḥ /
analyzed: trīṇi yānāni ayānam ca buddhānām na asti nirvṛtiḥ
translated: There are three vehicles and one vehicle, but the Buddhas do not have nirvāṇa.

original: buddhatve vyākṛtāḥ sarve vītadeṣāśca deśitāḥ // //🔽abhisamayāntikaṃ jñānaṃ nirupādigatistathā /
analyzed: buddhatve vyākṛtāḥ sarve vīta deṣāḥ ca deśitāḥ  abhisamaya antikam jñānam nirupādi gatiḥ tathā
translated: All are prophesied to Buddhahood, and those free from faults are taught.

original: protsāhanā ca līnānāmetatsaṃghāya deśitam // //🔽buddhairutpāditaṃ jñānaṃ mārgastaireva deśitaḥ /
analyzed: protsāhanā ca līnānām etat saṃghāya deśitam  buddhaiḥ utpāditam jñānam mārgaḥ taiḥ eva deśitaḥ
translated: The knowledge at the end of realization, the attainment without remainder, and the encouragement of the fainthearted - this is taught with that in mind.

original: yānti tenaiva nānyena atasteṣāṃ na nirvṛtiḥ // //
analyzed: yānti tena eva na anyena atas teṣām na nirvṛtiḥ
translated: The knowledge produced by the Buddhas, the path taught by them alone, they go by that alone, not by anything else, therefore they do not have nirvāṇa.

analyzed: bhava kāma rūpa dṛṣṭīnām vāsanāḥ vai caturvidhā
translated: The latent tendencies of existence, desire, form, and views are of four kinds.

analyzed: manaḥ vijñāna saṃbhūtāḥ ālayam ca manaḥ sthitāḥ  manaḥ vijñāna netra ādyaiḥ ucchedaḥ ca api anityataḥ
translated: Arisen from the mind consciousness, and the store consciousness abides in the mind.🔽Annihilation is from the mind consciousness, eyes, etc., and also from impermanence.

analyzed: śāśvatam ca anādyena nirvāṇa mati dṛṣṭinām
translated: Eternality is from the beginningless view of nirvāṇa.

analyzed: iti laṅkāvatāra sūtre nairmāṇika parivartaḥ saptamaḥ
translated: Thus ends the seventh chapter in the Laṅkāvatāra Sūtra, on the emanation body.

analyzed: māṃsabhakṣaṇaparivartaḥ nāma aṣṭamaḥ
translated: Chapter 8: On Eating Meat

original: atha khalu mahāmatirbodhisattvo mahāsattvo bhagavantaṃ gāthābhiḥ paripṛcchaya punarapyadhyeṣate smadeśayatu me bhagavāṃstathāgato'rhan samyaksaṃbuddho māṃsabhakṣaṇe guṇadoṣam /
analyzed: atha khalu mahāmatiḥ bodhisattvaḥ mahāsattvaḥ bhagavantam gāthābhiḥ punar api adhyeṣate sma deśayatu me bhagavān tathāgataḥ ūrhan samyaksaṃbuddhaḥ māṃsa bhakṣaṇe guṇa doṣam
translated: Then the bodhisattva mahāsattva Mahāmati, having questioned the Blessed One with verses, again requested: May the Blessed One, the Tathāgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One, teach me the virtues and faults of eating meat,

original: yena ahaṃ ca anye ca bodhisattvā mahāsattvā anāgatapratyutpannakāle sattvānāṃ kravyādasattvagativāsanāvāsitānāṃ māṃsabhojagṛddhāṇāṃ rasatṛṣṇāprahāṇāya dharmaṃ deśayāma /
analyzed: yena aham ca anye ca bodhisattvāḥ mahāsattvāḥ anāgata pratyutpanna kāle sattvānām kravyāda sattva gati vāsanā vāsitānām māṃsa bhoja gṛddhāṇām rasa tṛṣṇā prahāṇāya dharmam deśayāma
translated: so that I and other bodhisattva mahāsattvas may, in the future and present, teach the Dharma to beings who are inclined to the ways of carnivorous beings, who crave eating meat, in order to eliminate their craving for tastes.

original: yathā ca te kravyādabhojinaḥ sattvā virāgya rasatṛṣṇāṃ dharmarasāhārakāṅkṣayā sarvasattvaikaputrakapremānugatāḥ parasparaṃ mahāmaitrīṃ pratilabheran
analyzed: yathā ca te kravyāda bhojinaḥ sattvāḥ virāgya rasa tṛṣṇām dharma rasa āhāra kāṅkṣayā sarva sattva eka putraka prema anugatāḥ parasparam mahā maitrīm pratilabheran
translated: So that those beings who eat meat, having abandoned their craving for tastes, with a desire for the taste of the Dharma, filled with love for all beings as if they were their only child, may attain great friendliness towards each other.

analyzed: pratilabhya sarva bodhisattva bhūmiṣu kṛta yogyāḥ kṣipram anuttarām samyaksaṃbodhim abhisaṃbudhyeran
translated: Having attained that, having become fit for all the bodhisattva stages, may they quickly fully awaken to unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.

original: śrāvakapratyekabuddhabhūmyā vā viśramya anuttarāṃ tāthāgatīṃ bhūmimupasarpayeyuḥ /
analyzed: śrāvaka pratyekabuddha bhūmyāḥ vā viśramya anuttarām tāthāgatīm bhūmim upasarpayeyuḥ
translated: Or, having rested in the stage of the śrāvakas and pratyekabuddhas, they might approach the unsurpassed stage of the Tathāgatas.

analyzed: durākhyāta dharmaiḥ api tāvat bhagavan anya tīrthikaiḥ lokāyata dṛṣṭi abhiniviṣṭaiḥ sat asat pakṣa uccheda śāśvata vādibhiḥ māsam nivāryate bhakṣyamāṇam
translated: Even the poorly taught non-Buddhist teachers, O Blessed One, who are attached to the views of Lokāyatas, who advocate the annihilation of existence and non-existence, and who advocate eternalism, prevent meat from being eaten.

analyzed: svayam ca na bhakṣyate
translated: And they themselves do not eat it.

analyzed: prāk eva kṛpā ekarase samyaksaṃbuddhe praṇīte lokanāthe
translated: How much more so in the case of the Perfectly Awakened One, the Lord of the World, who is devoted solely to compassion and is excellent?

original: tava śāsane māṃsaṃ svayaṃ ca bhakṣyate /
analyzed: tava śāsane māṃsam svayam ca bhakṣyate
translated: In your teaching, meat is eaten by oneself.

analyzed: bhakṣyamāṇam ca na nivāryate
translated: And while being eaten, it is not prevented.

original: tatsādhu bhagavān sarvalokānukampakaḥ sarvasattvaiputrakasamadarśī mahākāruṇiko'nukampāmupādāya māṃsabhakṣaṇe guṇadeṣān deśayatu me /
analyzed: tat sādhu bhagavān sarva loka anukampakaḥ sarva sattva aiputraka sama darśī mahā kāruṇikaḥ nukampām upādāya māṃsa bhakṣaṇe guṇa deṣān deśayatu me
translated: Therefore, it is good if the Blessed One, who has compassion for all worlds, who sees all beings as his own children, the greatly compassionate one, out of compassion, would teach me the virtues and faults of eating meat.

original: yathā ahaṃ ca anye ca bodhisattvāstathatvāya sattvebhyo dharmaṃ deśayema /
analyzed: yathā aham ca anye ca bodhisattvāḥ tathatvāya sattvebhyaḥ dharmam deśayema
translated: So that I and other bodhisattvas may teach the Dharma to beings in accordance with the truth.

analyzed: bhagavān ahatena hi mahāmate śṛṇu
translated: The Blessed One said: Then, Mahāmati, listen.

analyzed: sādhu ca suṣṭhu ca manasikuru
translated: Listen well and properly, and keep it in mind.

analyzed: bhāṣiṣye iham te
translated: I will teach it to you.

original: sādhu bhagavanniti mahāmatirbodhisattvo mahāsattvo bhagavataḥ pratyaśrauṣīt //
analyzed: sādhu bhagavan iti mahāmatiḥ bodhisattvaḥ mahāsattvaḥ bhagavataḥ pratyaśrauṣīt
translated: The Bodhisattva Mahāmati replied, Excellent, Blessed One! and listened.

analyzed: bhagavān tasya etat avocata aparimitaiḥ mahāmate kāraṇaiḥ māṃsam sarvam abhakṣyam kṛpā ātmanaḥ bodhisattvasya
translated: The Blessed One said this to him: Mahāmati, for limited reasons, meat is forbidden to the compassionate Bodhisattva.

analyzed: tebhyaḥ tu upadeśa mātram vakṣyāmi
translated: I will teach you about them.

original: iha mahāmate anena dīrgheṇādhvanā saṃsaratāṃ prāṇināṃ nāstyasau kaścitsattvaḥ sulabharūpo yo na mātābhūtpitā vā bhrātā vā bhaginī vā putro vā duhitā vā anyatarānyataro vā svajanabandhubandhūbhūto vā /
analyzed: iha mahāmate anena dīrgheṇa adhvanā saṃsaratām prāṇinām na asti asau kaścid sattvaḥ sulabha rūpaḥ yaḥ na mātā abhūt pitā vā bhrātā vā bhaginī vā putraḥ vā duhitā vā anyatara anyataraḥ vā sva jana bandhu bandhūbhūtaḥ vā
translated: Mahāmati, in this long journey of transmigration, there is no being whatsoever who has not been a mother, father, brother, sister, son, daughter, or some other relative or friend to those who are wandering.

original: tasya anyajanmaparivṛttāśrayasya mṛgapaśupakṣiyonyantarbhūtasya bandhorbandhubhūtasya vā sarvabhūtātmabhūtānupāgantukāmena sarvajantuprāṇibhūtasaṃbhūtaṃ māṃsaṃ kathamiva bhakṣyaṃ syādbuddhadharmakāmena bodhisattvena mahāsattvena /
analyzed: tasya anya janma parivṛtta āśrayasya mṛga paśu pakṣi yoni antarbhūtasya bandhoḥ bandhu bhūtasya vā sarva bhūta ātma bhūta an upāgantu kāmena sarva jantu prāṇi bhūta saṃbhūtam māṃsam katham iva bhakṣyam syāt buddha dharma kāmena bodhisattvena mahāsattvena
translated: For one who has gone through many births and has become an animal, bird, or other creature, whether a relative or not, how can meat be eaten by one who desires to attain the nature of all beings and who desires the Dharma of the Buddha, if one is a Bodhisattva, a great being?

original: rākṣasasyāpi mahāmate tathāgatānāmimāṃ dharmasudharmatāmupaśrutya upagatarakṣabhāvāḥ kṛpālavā bhavanti māṃsabhakṣaṇavinivṛttāḥ /
analyzed: rākṣasasya api mahāmate tathāgatānām imām dharma su dharma tām upaśrutya upagata rakṣa bhāvāḥ kṛpā lavāḥ bhavanti māṃsa bhakṣaṇa vinivṛttāḥ
translated: Even a demon, O greatly wise one, when he hears this Dharma-nature of the Tathāgatas, becomes compassionate and turns away from eating flesh, having attained the state of a protector.

analyzed: kim uta dharma kāmāḥ janāḥ
translated: How much more so for people who desire the Dharma.

original: evaṃ tāvanmahāmate teṣu teṣu jātiparivarteṣu sarvasattvāḥ svajanabandhubhāvasaṃjñāḥ sarvasattvaikaputrakasaṃjñābhāvanārthaṃ māṃsaṃ sarvamabhakṣyam
analyzed: evam tāvat mahāmate teṣu teṣu jāti parivarteṣu sarva sattvāḥ sva jana bandhu bhāva saṃjñāḥ sarva sattva eka putraka saṃjñā bhāvanā artham māṃsam sarvam abhakṣyam
translated: Thus, O greatly wise one, in all the changes of birth, all beings have the perception of being one's own relatives and friends. For the sake of cultivating the perception of all beings as one's only child, all flesh is forbidden to be eaten.

analyzed: kṛpā ātmanaḥ bodhisattvasya abhakṣyam māṃsam
translated: Flesh is forbidden to be eaten by the compassionate Bodhisattva.

original: vyabhicārādapi mahāmate māṃsaṃ sarvamabhakṣyaṃ cāritravato bodhisattvasya /
analyzed: vyabhicārāt api mahāmate māṃsam sarvam abhakṣyam cāritravataḥ bodhisattvasya
translated: O greatly wise one, flesh is also forbidden to be eaten by the Bodhisattva who has good conduct, because of transgression.

analyzed: śva khara uṣṭra aśva balīvarda mānuṣa māṃsa ādīni hi mahāmate lokasya abhakṣyāṇi māṃsāni
translated: O greatly wise one, flesh such as that of dogs, donkeys, camels, horses, oxen, humans, and so on, which are forbidden to be eaten by the world,

original: tāni ca mahāmate vīthyantareṣvaurabhrikā bhakṣyāṇīti kṛtvā mūlyahetorvikrīyante yataḥ /
analyzed: tāni ca mahāmate vīthi antareṣu aurabhrikāḥ bhakṣyāṇi iti kṛtvā mūlya hetoḥ vikrīyante yatas
translated: are sold by butchers in the streets, O greatly wise one, as if they were edible, for the sake of profit.

analyzed: tatas api mahāmate māṃsam abhakṣyam bodhisattvasya
translated: Therefore, O greatly wise one, flesh is forbidden to be eaten by the Bodhisattva.

analyzed: śukra śoṇita saṃbhavāt api mahāmate śuci kāma tām upādāya bodhisattvasya māṃsam abhakṣyam
translated: “Also, O Mahāmati, the flesh of living beings is not to be eaten by the Bodhisattva, because of the desire for purity, since it is produced from semen and blood.

original: udvejanakaratvādapi mahāmate bhūtānāṃ maitrīmicchato yogino māṃsaṃ sarvamabhakṣyaṃ bodhisattvasya /
analyzed: udvejana kara tvāt api mahāmate bhūtānām maitrīm icchataḥ yoginaḥ māṃsam sarvam abhakṣyam bodhisattvasya
translated: “Also, O Mahāmati, all flesh is not to be eaten by the Bodhisattva, because it causes fear, since he desires friendliness for all beings and is a yogin.

original: tadyathāpi mahāmate ḍombacāṇḍālakaivartādīn piśitāśinaḥ sattvān dūrata eva dṛṣṭvā śvānaḥ prabhayanti bhayena /
analyzed: tat yathā api mahāmate ḍomba cāṇḍāla kaivarta ādīn piśita āśinaḥ sattvān dūratas eva dṛṣṭvā śvānaḥ prabhayanti bhayena
translated: “For example, O Mahāmati, dogs bark at the sight of Dombas, Caṇḍālas, and fishermen, who eat flesh, from a distance, out of fear.

analyzed: maraṇa prāptāḥ ca eke bhavanti asmān api mārayiṣyanti iti
translated: And some of them are in danger of death, thinking, ‘They will kill us too.’

original: evameva mahāmate anye'pi khabhūjalasaṃniśritān sūkṣmajantavo ye māṃsāśino darśanāddūrādeva paṭunā ghrāṇenāghrāya gandhaṃ rākṣasasyeva mānuṣā
analyzed: evam eva mahāmate anye api kha bhū jala saṃniśritān sūkṣma jantavaḥ ye māṃsa āśinaḥ darśanāt dūrāt eva paṭunā ghrāṇena āghrāya gandham rākṣasasya iva mānuṣā
translated: In the same way, O Mahāmati, other small creatures living in the sky, on the earth, and in the water, when they see those who eat flesh, are frightened from a distance, smelling the odor with their keen noses, like demons.

analyzed: maraṇa saṃdehāḥ ca eke bhavanti
translated: And some of them are in danger of death.

original: tasmādapi ca mahāmate udvejanakaratvānmahāmaitrīvihāriṇo yogino māṃsamabhakṣyaṃ bodhisattvasya anāryajanajuṣṭaṃ durgandham /
analyzed: tasmāt api ca mahāmate udvejana kara tvāt mahā maitrī vihāriṇaḥ yoginaḥ māṃsam abhakṣyam bodhisattvasya an ārya jana juṣṭam durgandham
translated: Therefore, O Mahāmati, flesh is not to be eaten by the Bodhisattva, the yogin who dwells in great friendliness, because it causes fear, is enjoyed by ignoble people, and smells bad.

analyzed: a kīrti kara tvāt api mahāmate ārya jana vivarjita tvāt ca māṃsam abhakṣyam bodhisattvasya
translated: For the sake of avoiding infamy, and because it is shunned by the noble ones, the wise one should not eat meat.

original: ṛṣibhojanāhāro hi mahāmate āryajano na māṃsarudhirāhāraḥ /
analyzed: ṛṣi bhojana āhāraḥ hi mahāmate ārya janaḥ na māṃsa rudhira āhāraḥ
translated: The noble ones, O Mahamati, subsist on the food of sages, not on meat and blood.

analyzed: iti atas api bodhisattvasya māṃsam abhakṣyam
translated: For this reason also, the bodhisattva should not eat meat.

original: bahujanacittānurakṣaṇatayāpi apavādaparihāraṃ cecchataḥ śāsanasya mahāmate māṃsamabhakṣyaṃ kṛpātmano bodhisattvasya /
analyzed: bahu jana citta anurakṣaṇa tayā api apavāda parihāram ca icchataḥ śāsanasya mahāmate māṃsam abhakṣyam kṛpā ātmanaḥ bodhisattvasya
translated: For the sake of protecting the minds of many people, and for the sake of avoiding criticism, the compassionate bodhisattva should not eat meat, O Mahamati, if he wishes to preserve the teachings.

analyzed: tat yathā mahāmate bhavanti loke śāsana apavāda vaktāraḥ
translated: For there are, O Mahamati, some in the world who criticize the teachings, saying:

analyzed: kiṃcid teṣām śrāmaṇyam
translated: What do they have of the life of a recluse?

analyzed: kutas vā brāhmaṇyam
translated: Or how can they be Brahmins?

original: yannāmaite pūrvarṣibhojanānyapāsya kravyādā ivāmiṣāhārāḥ paripūrṇakukṣayaḥ khabhūmijalasaṃniśritān sūkṣmāṃstrāsayanto jantūn samutrāsayanta imaṃ lokaṃ samantataḥ paryaṭanti /
analyzed: yat nāma ete pūrva ṛṣi bhojanāni apāsya kravyādāḥ iva āmiṣa āhārāḥ paripūrṇa kukṣayaḥ kha bhūmi jala saṃniśritān sūkṣmān trāsayantaḥ jantūn samutrāsayantaḥ imam lokam samantataḥ paryaṭanti
translated: For they have abandoned the food of the sages of old, and like flesh-eaters they wander about this world on all sides, terrifying the tiny creatures that live in the air, on the ground, and in the water, with their bellies full of meat.

analyzed: nihatam eṣām śrāmaṇyam
translated: Their life of a recluse is destroyed.

analyzed: dhvastam eṣām brāhmaṇyam
translated: Their Brahminhood is lost.

analyzed: na asti eṣām dharmaḥ na vinayaḥ
translated: They have no Dharma, no discipline.

analyzed: iti aneka prakāra pratihata cetasaḥ śāsanam eva apavadanti
translated: Thus, with their minds obstructed by many kinds of wrong views, they slander the very teaching.

original: tasmādbahujanacittānurakṣaṇatayāpi apavādaparihāraṃ cecchataḥ śāsanasya mahāmate māṃsaṃṃ sarvamabhakṣyaṃ kṛpātmano bodhisattvasya //
analyzed: tasmāt bahu jana citta anurakṣaṇa tayā api apavāda parihāram ca icchataḥ śāsanasya mahāmate māṃsaṃṃ sarvam abhakṣyam kṛpā ātmanaḥ bodhisattvasya
translated: Therefore, even for the sake of protecting the minds of many people, one who wishes to avoid slander of the teaching, O Mahāmati, should not eat any meat, for the compassionate bodhisattva.

analyzed: mṛta śava durgandha pratikūla sāmānyāt api mahāmate māṃsam abhakṣyam bodhisattvasya
translated: Meat is also inedible for the bodhisattva because of the commonality of repulsiveness due to the smell of a dead body, O Mahāmati.

original: mṛtasyāpi hi mahāmate manuṣyasya māṃse dahyamāne tadanyaprāṇimāṃse ca /
analyzed: mṛtasya api hi mahāmate manuṣyasya māṃse dahyamāne tad anya prāṇi māṃse ca
translated: For even when the flesh of a dead human is being burned, O Mahāmati, and the flesh of other animals,

analyzed: na kaścid gandha viśeṣaḥ
translated: there is no special smell.

analyzed: samam ubhaya māṃsayoḥ dahyamānayoḥ daurgandhyam
translated: The foul smell of both kinds of burning flesh is the same.

original: ato'pi mahāmate śucikāmasya yoginaḥ sarvaṃ māṃsamabhakṣyaṃ bodhisattvasya //
analyzed: atas upi mahāmate śuci kāmasya yoginaḥ sarvam māṃsam abhakṣyam bodhisattvasya
translated: Therefore, O Mahāmati, meat is inedible for the bodhisattva, the yogi who desires purity.

original: śmaśānikānāṃ ca mahāmate araṇyavanaprasthānyamanuṣyāvacarāṇi prāntāni śayanāsanānyadhyāvasatāṃ yogināṃ yogācārāṇāṃ maitrīvihāriṇāṃ vidyādharāṇāṃ vidyāṃ sādhayitukāmānāṃ vidyāsādhanamokṣavighnakaratvānmahāyānasaṃprasthitānāṃ kulaputrāṇāṃ kuladuhitṝṇāṃ ca sarvayogasādhanāntarāyakaramityapi samanupaśyatāṃ mahāmate svaparātmahitakāmasya māṃsaṃ sarvamabhakṣyaṃ bodhisattvasya /
analyzed: śmaśānikānām ca mahāmate araṇya vanaprasthāni amanuṣyāvacarāṇi prāntāni śayanāsanāni adhyāvasatām yoginām yoga ācārāṇām maitrī vihāriṇām vidyādharāṇām vidyām sādhayitu kāmānām vidyā sādhana mokṣa vighna kara tvāt mahāyāna saṃprasthitānām kula putrāṇām kula duhitṝṇām ca sarva yoga sādhana antarāya karam iti api samanupaśyatām mahāmate sva para ātma hita kāmasya māṃsam sarvam abhakṣyam bodhisattvasya anupūrva anupūrva anupūrva anu
translated: And, O thou of great intelligence, for those who dwell in cemeteries, in the forests and wildernesses, in uninhabited regions, in beds and seats at the outskirts, for yogis and yoginis, for those who abide in friendliness, for Vidyadharas who desire to accomplish Vidyas, for sons and daughters of good family who have set out in the Great Vehicle, and for those who see that meat is an obstacle to the attainment of liberation and the accomplishment of Vidyas, for those who desire their own and others' welfare, all meat is forbidden to the Bodhisattva, O thou of great intelligence.

analyzed: rūpa ālambana vijñāna pratyaya āsvāda janaka tvāt api sarva bhūta ātma bhūtasya kṛpā ātmanaḥ sarvam māṃsam abhakṣyam bodhisattvasya
translated: Because it produces the taste that arises from consciousness having form as its object, and because it is the essence of all beings, all meat is forbidden to the Bodhisattva, who is compassionate by nature.

original: devatā api cainaṃ parivarjayantīti kṛtvā mahāmate kṛpātmanaḥ sarvaṃ māṃsamabhakṣyaṃ bodhisattvasya /
analyzed: devatāḥ api ca enam parivarjayanti iti kṛtvā mahāmate kṛpā ātmanaḥ sarvam māṃsam abhakṣyam bodhisattvasya
translated: And because even the gods avoid him, all meat is forbidden to the Bodhisattva, O thou of great intelligence, who is compassionate by nature.

analyzed: mukham ca asya parama durgandhi iha eva tāvat janmani
translated: And his mouth has a very bad smell even in this very life.

original: ityapi kṛtvā mahāmate kṛpātmanaḥ sarvaṃ māṃsamabhakṣyaṃ bodhisattvasya /🔽duḥkhaṃ svapiti /
analyzed: iti api kṛtvā mahāmate kṛpā ātmanaḥ sarvam māṃsam abhakṣyam bodhisattvasya  duḥkham svapiti
translated: For this reason, O Mahāmati, the Bodhisattva, the compassionate one, should not eat any meat at all.🔽He sleeps badly.

analyzed: duḥkham pratibudhyate
translated: He wakes up badly.

analyzed: pāpakān ca roma harṣaṇān svapnān paśyanti
translated: He sees evil dreams that make the hair stand on end.

analyzed: śūnya āgāra sthitasya ca ekākinaḥ rahaḥ gatasya viharataḥ usya amanuṣyāḥ tejaḥ haranti
translated: When he stays in an empty house, alone, secluded, and lives [there], non-human beings take away his energy.

analyzed: utrasyanti api
translated: He is afraid.

analyzed: kadācid saṃtrasyanti api
translated: Sometimes he is terrified.

analyzed: saṃtrāsam akasmāt ca āpadyante
translated: He suddenly experiences terror.

original: āhāre ca mātrāṃ na jānāti nāpyaśitapītakhāditākhāditasya samyagrasapariṇāmapuṣṭyādi samāsādayati /
analyzed: āhāre ca mātrām na jānāti na api aśita pīta khādita ākhāditasya samyak rasa pariṇāma puṣṭi ādi samāsādayati
translated: And he does not know moderation in food. Nor does he attain proper digestion and nourishment from what he has eaten, drunk, chewed, and tasted.

analyzed: krimi jantu pracura kuṣṭha nidāna koṣṭhaḥ ca bhavati vyādhi bahulam
translated: And his stomach becomes full of worms and other creatures, and a source of leprosy, and full of diseases.

analyzed: na ca pratikūla saṃjñām pratilabhate
translated: And he does not attain the perception of what is disagreeable.

original: putramāṃsabhaiṣajyavadāhāraṃ deśayaṃścāhaṃ mahāmate kathamiva anāryajanasevitamāryajanavivarjitamevamanekadoṣāvahamanekaguṇavivarjitamanṛṣibhojanapraṇītamakalpyaṃ māṃsarudhirāhāraṃ śiṣyebhyo'nujñāpyāmi /
analyzed: putra māṃsa bhaiṣajya vat āhāram deśayan ca aham mahāmate katham iva anārya jana sevitam ārya jana vivarjitam evam aneka doṣa āvaham aneka guṇa vivarjitam an ṛṣi bhojana praṇītam akalpyam māṃsa rudhira āhāram śiṣyebhyaḥ anujñāpyāmi
translated: And when I teach the Dharma, comparing food to the medicine of one's own son, O Mahāmati, how can I allow my disciples to eat meat and blood, which is used by non-noble people, avoided by noble people, full of so many faults, devoid of so many virtues, and not recommended by the sages, which is not suitable?

analyzed: anujñātavān punar aham mahāmate sarva ārya jana sevitam an ārya jana vivarjitam aneka guṇa vāhakam aneka doṣa vivarjitam sarva pūrva ṛṣi praṇītam bhojanam
translated: Again, O Mahāmati, I have permitted food that is used by all noble people and avoided by ignoble people, which carries many virtues and is free from many faults, and which has been prescribed by all the ancient sages.

analyzed: yat uta śāli yava godhūma mudga māṣa masūrī ādi sarpiḥ taila madhu phāṇita guḍa khaṇḍa matsyaṇḍikā ādiṣu samupapadyamānam bhojanam kalpyam iti kṛtvā
translated: Namely, food that is suitable among rice, barley, wheat, mung beans, black gram, lentil, etc., ghee, oil, honey, molasses, sugar, rock candy, fish, etc., considering it to be proper.

original: na ca mahāmate anāgate'dhvani ekeṣāṃ mohapuruṣāṇāṃ vividhavinayavikalpavādināṃ kravyādakulavāsitāvāsitānāṃ rasatṛṣṇāvyavasitānāmidaṃ praṇītaṃ bhojanaṃ pratibhāṣyate /
analyzed: na ca mahāmate anāgata idhvani ekeṣām moha puruṣāṇām vividha vinaya vikalpa vādinām kravyāda kula vāsi tā vāsitānām rasa tṛṣṇā vyavasitānām idam praṇītam bhojanam pratibhāṣyate
translated: But, O Mahāmati, in the future time, this excellent food will not be approved by some deluded people who propound various disciplines, who are habituated in the dwelling of carnivorous families, and who are attached to the craving for taste.

original: na tu mahāmate pūrvajinakṛtādhikārāṇāmavaropitakuśalamūlānāṃ śrāddhānāmavikalpānāṃ bahulānāṃ śākyakulakulīnānāṃ kulaputrāṇāṃ kuladuhitṝṇāṃ kāyajīvitabhogānadhyavasitānāmarasagṛdhrāṇāmalolupānāṃ kṛpālūnāṃ sarvabhūtātmabhūtatāmupagantukāmānāṃ sarvasattvaikaputrakapriyadarśināṃ bodhisattvānāṃ mahāsattvānamiti vadāmi //
analyzed: na tu mahāmate pūrva jina kṛta adhikārāṇām avaropita kuśala mūlānām śrāddhānām avikalpānām bahulānām śākya kula kulīnānām kula putrāṇām kula duhitṝṇām kāya jīvita bhoga anadhyavasitānām arasa gṛdhrāṇām a lolupānām kṛpālūnām sarva bhūta ātma bhūta tām upagantu kāmānām sarva sattva eka putraka priya darśinām bodhisattvānām mahāsattvānam iti vadāmi
translated: But, O Mahāmati, I do not say this of the Bodhisattva-Mahāsattvas who have previously served the Jinas, planted the roots of merit, are faithful, free from discrimination, numerous, of noble Shakya family, sons and daughters of noble families, who are not attached to body, life, or possessions, who are not greedy, are compassionate, who wish to attain the state of self-identity with all beings, who see all beings as their only child, who are Bodhisattvas, Mahāsattvas.

analyzed: bhūta pūrvam mahāmate atīta idhvani rājā abhūt siṃhasaudāsaḥ nāma
translated: In the past, O Mahāmati, there was a king named Siṃha-saudāsa.

original: sa māṃsabhojanāhārātiprasaṅgena pratisevamāno rasatṛṣṇādhyavasānaparamatayā māṃsāni mānuṣyāṇyapi bhakṣitavān /
analyzed: sa māṃsa bhojana āhāra ati prasaṅgena pratisevamānaḥ rasa tṛṣṇā adhyavasāna parama tayā māṃsāni mānuṣyāṇi api bhakṣitavān
translated: He, being excessively attached to the enjoyment of meat food, due to his extreme craving for taste, ate even human flesh.

analyzed: tad nidānam ca mitra amātya jñāti bandhu vargeṇa api parityaktaḥ
translated: And on that account, he was abandoned even by his friends, ministers, relatives, and kinsmen.

analyzed: prāk eva paura jānapadaiḥ
translated: How much more so by the citizens and country people.

analyzed: sva rājya viṣaya parityāgāt ca mahat vayasanam āsāditavān māṃsa hetoḥ
translated: And because of the abandonment of his own kingdom and territory, he met with great calamity, for the sake of meat.

original: indreṇāpi ca mahāmate devādhipatyaṃ prāptena pūrvābhūtvā
analyzed: indreṇa api ca mahāmate deva ādhipatyam prāptena pūrvā a bhūtvā
translated: Even by Indra, O Mahāmati, having attained lordship over the gods in the past,

analyzed: pūrva janma māṃsa āda vāsanā doṣāt śyena rūpam āsthāya kapota veṣa rūpa dhārī viśvakarmā
translated: Due to the fault of the latent tendencies of eating meat from previous births, he took on the form of a hawk and pursued Vishvakarma, who had taken on the form of a dove.

analyzed: tulāyām ca ātmānam āropitaḥ āsīt
translated: And he weighed himself on a scale.

original: yasmādrājā anaparādhibhūtānukampakaḥ śibī duḥkhena mahatā lambhitaḥ /
analyzed: yasmāt rājā anaparādhi bhūta anukampakaḥ śibī duḥkhena mahatā lambhitaḥ
translated: Because King Shibi, who had compassion for the innocent, was greatly afflicted with suffering.

original: tadevamanekajanmābhyastamapi mahāmate devendrabhūtasya śakrasyāpi sataḥ svaparadoṣāvahanamabhūt /
analyzed: tat evam aneka janma abhyastam api mahāmate deva indra bhūtasya śakrasya api sataḥ sva para doṣa āvahanam abhūt
translated: Thus, even for the greatly wise Shakra, who was born as the lord of the gods in many births, there was the bringing of harm to himself and others.

analyzed: prāk eva tat anyeṣām
translated: How much more so for others!

original: anyeṣāṃ ca mahāmate narendrabhūtānāṃ satāmaśvenāpahṛtānāmaṭavyāṃ paryaṭamānānāṃ siṃhyā saha maithunaṃ gatavatāṃ jīvitabhayādapatyāni cotpāditavantaḥ siṃhasaṃvāsānvayātkalmāṣapādaprabhṛtayo nṛpaputrāḥ pūrvajanmamāṃsādadoṣavāsanatayā manuṣyendrabhūtā api santo māṃsādā abhūvan /
analyzed: anyeṣām ca mahāmate narendra bhūtānām satām aśvena apahṛtānām aṭavyām paryaṭamānānām siṃhyā saha maithunam gatavatām jīvita bhayāt apatyāni ca utpāditavantaḥ siṃha saṃvāsa anvayāt kalmāṣapāda prabhṛtayaḥ nṛpa putrāḥ pūrva janma māṃsāda doṣa vāsanatayā manuṣya indra bhūtāḥ api santaḥ māṃsādāḥ abhūvan
translated: And for others, O greatly wise one, who were born as human kings, when they were carried away by a horse and wandered in the forest, having intercourse with a lioness out of fear for their lives, and begot offspring, due to the connection with a lion, kings such as Kalmashapada and others, even though born as human kings due to the latent tendencies of the fault of eating meat in previous births, became meat-eaters.

original: ihaiva ca mahāmate janmani saptakuṭīrake'pi grāme pracuramāṃsalaulyādatiprasaṅgena niṣevamānā mānuṣamāṃsādā ghorā ḍākā vā ḍākinyaśca saṃjāyante
analyzed: iha eva ca mahāmate janmani sapta kuṭīrake pi grāme pracura māṃsa laulyāt atiprasaṅgena niṣevamānāḥ mānuṣa māṃsa ādāḥ ghorāḥ ḍākāḥ vā ḍākinyaḥ ca saṃjāyante
translated: And, O Mahamati, even in this very life, in a village of seven huts, they are born as terrible male or female demons who eat human flesh, due to excessive indulgence out of greed for abundant flesh.

original: jātiparivarte ca mahāmate tathaiva māṃsarasādhyavasānatayā siṃhavyāghradvīpivṛkatarakṣumārjārajambukolūkādipracuramāṃsādayoniṣu pracuratarapiśitāśanā rākṣasādighoratarayoniṣu vinipātyante /
analyzed: jāti parivarte ca mahāmate tathā eva māṃsa rasa adhyavasāna tayā siṃha vyāghra dvīpi vṛka tarakṣu mārjāra jambuka ulūka ādi pracura māṃsa āda yoniṣu pracuratara piśita aśanāḥ rākṣasa ādi ghoratara yoniṣu vinipātyante
translated: And, O Mahamati, in the change of birth, due to the strong attachment to the taste of meat, they are reborn in the wombs of lions, tigers, leopards, wolves, hyenas, cats, jackals, owls, and other creatures that eat abundant flesh, and in the terrible wombs of rakshasas and other such beings that eat abundant flesh.

analyzed: yatra vinipatitānām duḥkhena mānuṣya yoniḥ api samāpadyate
translated: Once fallen there, it is difficult for them to attain the human state.

analyzed: prāgave nirvṛtiḥ
translated: How much more so to attain nirvana.

original: ityevamādayo mahāmate māṃsādadoṣāḥ prāgeva niṣevamānānāṃ samupajāyante /
analyzed: iti evamādayaḥ mahāmate māṃsāt adoṣāḥ prāk eva niṣevamānānām samupajāyante
translated: Thus, O Mahamati, these and other faults arise for those who eat meat, even before they engage in it.

analyzed: viparyayāt ca bhūyāṃsaḥ guṇāḥ
translated: And there are many more virtues from the opposite [of those faults].

original: na ca mahāmate bālapṛthagjanā etāṃścānyāṃśca guṇadoṣānavabudhyante /
analyzed: na ca mahāmate bāla pṛthagjanāḥ etān ca anyān ca guṇa doṣān avabudhyante
translated: But, O Mahamati, childish ordinary beings do not understand these virtues and faults, nor others.

original: evamādiguṇadoṣadarśanānmahāmate māṃsaṃ sarvamabhakṣyaṃ kṛpātmano bodhisattvasyeti vadāmi //
analyzed: evamādi guṇa doṣa darśanāt mahāmate māṃsam sarvam abhakṣyam kṛpā ātmanaḥ bodhisattvasya iti vadāmi
translated: Seeing these virtues and faults, O Mahamati, I say that all meat is inedible for the compassionate bodhisattva.

original: yadi ca mahāmate māṃsaṃ na kathaṃcana kecana bhakṣayeyuḥ /
analyzed: yadi ca mahāmate māṃsam na kathaṃcana kecana bhakṣayeyuḥ
translated: And if, O Mahamati, no one would ever eat meat,

analyzed: na tad nidānam ghāteran
translated: they would not be killed for that reason.

original: mūlyahetorhi mahāmate prāyaḥ prāṇino niraparādhino vadhyante svalpādanyahetoḥ /
analyzed: mūlya hetoḥ hi mahāmate prāyas prāṇinaḥ niraparādhinaḥ vadhyante su alpāt anya hetoḥ
translated: For the sake of price, O Mahamati, living beings are mostly killed, even though innocent, for a small other reason.

original: kaṣṭaṃ mahāmate rasatṛṣṇāyāmatisevatāṃ māṃsāni mānuṣānyapi mānuṣairbhakṣyante /
analyzed: kaṣṭam mahāmate rasa tṛṣṇāyām atisevatām māṃsāni mānuṣāni api mānuṣaiḥ bhakṣyante
translated: It is a pity, O Mahamati, that those who excessively indulge in craving for taste eat even human flesh, O Mahamati,

analyzed: kim punar itara mṛga pakṣi prāṇi saṃbhūta māṃsāni
translated: let alone the flesh of other animals and birds.

original: prāyo mahāmate māṃsarasatṛṣṇārtairidaṃ tathā tathā jālayantramāviddhaṃ mohapuruṣaiḥ /
analyzed: prāyas mahāmate māṃsa rasa tṛṣṇā ārtaiḥ idam tathā tathā jālayantram āviddham moha puruṣaiḥ
translated: For the most part, O Mahamati, this net is spread in such and such a way by those afflicted with craving for meat, by deluded men.

analyzed: yat śākunika aurabhraka kaivarta ādayaḥ khecara bhūcara jalacarān prāṇinaḥ aparādhinaḥ aneka prakāram mūlya hetoḥ viśasanti
translated: By which fowlers, hunters, fishermen and others, innocent sky-walkers, land-walkers and water-walkers are slaughtered in many ways for the sake of price.

original: na caiṣāṃ mahāmate kiṃkanīkṛtarūkṣacetasāṃ rākṣasānāmiva gataghṛṇānāṃ kadācidapi prāṇiṣu prāṇisaṃjñayā ghātayatāṃ bhakṣayatāṃ na ghṛṇotpadyate
analyzed: na ca eṣām mahāmate kiṃkanīkṛta rūkṣa cetasām rākṣasānām iva gata ghṛṇānām kadācid api prāṇiṣu prāṇi saṃjñayā ghātayatām bhakṣayatām na ghṛṇā utpadyate
translated: And for those with minds made rough by greed, O Mahamati, like demons, devoid of compassion, who kill and eat living beings, never does compassion arise.

original: na ca mahāmate akṛtakamakāritamasaṃkalpitaṃ nāma māṃsaṃ kalpyamasti yadupādāya anujānīyāṃ śrāvakebhyaḥ /
analyzed: na ca mahāmate akṛtakam akāritam asaṃkalpitam nāma māṃsam kalpyam asti yat upādāya anujānīyām śrāvakebhyaḥ
translated: And, Mahāmati, there is no such thing as uncreated, unmade, unpurposed meat, on the basis of which I could allow it to my disciples.

original: bhaviṣyanti tu punarmahāmate anāgate'dhvani mamaiva śāsane pravrajitvā śākyaputrīyatvaṃ pratijānānāḥ kāṣāyadhvajadhāriṇo mohapuruṣā mithyāvitarkopahatacetaso vividhavinayavikalpavādinaḥ satkāyadṛṣṭiyuktā rasatṛṣṇādhyavasitāstāṃ tāṃ māṃsabhakṣaṇahetvābhāsāṃ granthayiṣyanti /
analyzed: bhaviṣyanti tu punar mahāmate anāgata idhvani mama eva śāsane pravrajitvā śākyaputrīya tvam pratijānānāḥ kāṣāya dhvaja dhāriṇaḥ moha puruṣāḥ mithyā vitarka upahata cetasaḥ vividha vinaya vikalpa vādinaḥ satkāya dṛṣṭi yuktāḥ rasa tṛṣṇā adhyavasitāḥ tām tām māṃsa bhakṣaṇa hetu ābhāsām granthayiṣyanti
translated: But, Mahāmati, in the future there will be deluded men in my own order who will claim to be sons of the Śākyas, wear the saffron robe, and be deluded by false thoughts, who will teach various kinds of discipline, who will be attached to the view of the real existence of the body and to the craving for tastes, and they will compose various false reasons for eating meat.

original: mama cābhūtābhyākhyānaṃ dātavyaṃ maṃsyante /🔽tattadarthotpattinidānaṃ kalpayitvā vakṣyantiiyamarthotpattirasminnidāne /
analyzed: mama ca abhūta abhyākhyānam dātavyam maṃsyante  tad tad artha utpatti nidānam kalpayitvā vakṣyanti iyam artha utpattiḥ asmin nidāne
translated: And they will think that they should falsely accuse me.

analyzed: bhagavatā māṃsa bhojanam anujñātam kalpyam iti
translated: Having invented various stories about the origin of meat, they will say: This is the origin of meat, in this story the Blessed One allowed and approved the eating of meat.

analyzed: praṇīta bhojaneṣu ca uktam
translated: And in the case of refined foods it is said:

analyzed: svayam ca kila tathāgatena paribhuktam iti
translated: And it is said that the Tathāgata himself ate it.

analyzed: na ca mahāmate kutracid sūtre pratisevitavyam iti anujñātam
translated: But, Mahāmati, nowhere in the sūtras is it allowed to eat meat.

analyzed: praṇīta bhojaneṣu vā deśitam kalpyam iti
translated: Or it is prescribed for those who eat refined food.

original: yadi tu mahāmate anujñātukāmatā me syāt /
analyzed: yadi tu mahāmate anujñātu kāma tā me syāt
